Panel chairman Gareth Roberts said it was the appropriate sanction to "allow her to return to teaching within a short period of time". Their first stop on a busy day of public engagements was a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. The Unesco World Heritage Site is made up of some 40,000 large black basalt columns which protrude from the sea. It was the Royal couple's first visit to Northern Ireland's best known tourist attraction. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced up through fissures in the earth to form a lava plateau. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh then travelled to the nearby village of Bushmills to commemorate local soldier Robert Quigg. He won a Victoria Cross for bravery during the Battle of the Somme. Sgt Quigg was given the highest military award for valour after going out into the line of fire to search for his commanding officer. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh unveiled a statue of the soldier as well as a commemorative stone. His grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, also gave a short address. From there, the Royal couple moved on to a reception at Portrush Golf Club as guests of the mayor for the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. Afterwards, they took a journey back in time as they travelled on a steam train from Coleraine, County Londonderry, to the village of Bellarena. Large crowds gathered in Coleraine to greet the couple as they boarded the five-carriage train, built in 1932. The Royal guests were accompanied by local schoolchildren as they travelled to Bellarena, where the Queen officially opened the village's new train station. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh first made the same journey along the historic Coleraine to Londonderry railway line in 1953 - the year of her coronation. The original station had opened a century earlier in 1853. Earlier this year, two new railway platforms opened in Bellarena, as part of a Â£46m upgrade to the Coleraine to Londonderry railway line. On her arrival in the village, the Queen unveiled a plaque marking the new development. Wellwishers lined the route, waving union flags and cheering. On Monday, the Royal visitor met Northern Ireland's first and deputy first ministers at Hillsborough Castle in County Down. The trip is the third high-profile royal visit to Northern Ireland in weeks and follows on from appearances by the Prince of Wales and Duchess of Cornwall and then the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. The government said extra funds were being given to early years providers to help children from poorer backgrounds and close the attainment gap. Research by the IPPR showed only 47% of children born in the poorest families in the north of England achieved a good level of early years development compared with 59% in London. Its survey also found five northern city-regions combined had almost as many well-qualified individuals (3.6 million) as London (3.7 million) - but the IPPR forecasts demand for skilled workers in the North is set to increase. IPPR's director Ed Cox said: "We will never become a powerhouse economy when our children and young people have such a poor start in life. "It will take a generation of investment - not only in new railways and motorways, but in the 'human capital' of the north - in education and training, starting with the youngest. "If the Northern Powerhouse is to be successful, economic powers must be devolved to all corners of the North to allow businesses and policymakers to develop an economy that supports more productive, resilient and sustainable growth: jobs that pay well, prosperity that is shared, and opportunities for all." The Department for Education said it was committed to ensuring every child, regardless of background, could fulfil their potential. It said reforms had meant there were 250,000 more pupils in good or outstanding schools in the north since 2010.

Until now, Google Assistant had only been available on the firm's own Pixel phones. The service, like Siri on iPhones, allows users to interact with apps and ask questions. LG was one of the first smartphone makers to reveal it would feature the assistant on its new device, the G6. Google's update will starting rolling out this week to users with Android 6.0 Marshmallow or 7.0 Nougat installed. "With this update, hundreds of millions of Android users will now be able to try out the Google Assistant," said Gummi Hafsteinsson, product lead for Google Assistant, in a blog post. But other virtual assistants are out there. At the Mobile World Congress tech show in Barcelona, Lenovo Moto revealed that Amazon's Alexa assistant would be coming to the Moto Z phone. This will happen via an alternative back - known as a MotoMod - that Amazon will sell for the Moto Z later this year. And at the CES tech show in Las Vegas last month, Chinese tech giant Huawei announced it would include Amazon's rival Alexa assistant on its phones. Google Assistant differs from its competitors slightly in that it is designed to prompt conversations with users and respond to follow-up queries. "It is a natural step for Google to offer Google Assistant to as many smartphones as possible because AI is at the heart of Google's strategy, said tech analyst Ian Fogg at IHS Technology. "With the machine learning that underpins Google Assistant AI, the more people that use Assistant, the smarter it will become." Initially, Assistant will be available to English-speaking users in the United States. English-speaking users in Australia, Canada and the United Kingdom will receive the update next. Support for other languages will follow, Google said.

His Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), who had opposed the card readers, called it a "huge national embarrassment". But the number of job vacancies dropped by 18,000 to 745,000, the ONS added, marking the first fall for almost a year. David Freeman, a senior statistician at the ONS, said: "The employment rate has hit another record high, but this time the increase is quite modest. "With unemployment very little changed, that is further evidence the jobs market could be cooling off." Average earnings including bonuses rose 2% from a year earlier, up from 1.9% in the three months to February. The ONS said the timing of bonuses this year had affected the rise in total earnings. Excluding bonuses, earnings rose by 2.1% year-on-year in the three months to March, down from 2.2% in the three months to February. The number of people claiming jobless benefits fell by 2,400 in April to 737,800, although revised data showed the figure rose by 14,700 between February and March, the largest increase since autumn 2011. The Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, Stephen Crabb, said: "These are another record-breaking set of figures, with more people in work than ever before and the unemployment rate is the lowest in a decade at 5.1%." But economists were less upbeat. David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce, said that despite the UK employment rate reaching a record high, "the cumulative picture - including manufacturing, trade and GDP figures - points to a softening in economic activity". Paul Hollingsworth, UK economist at Capital Economics, said: "Although there were some bright spots in today's UK labour market figures, on the whole they offered a further indication that the economic slowdown has sapped the jobs recovery of its recent vigour." The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates as "fuel shortage in a film", became France's top Twitter trend on Tuesday, with more than 5,000 tweets. A strike over new labour laws is now affecting all of France's eight oil refineries. An estimated 20% of petrol stations have either run dry or are low on supplies. In their posts, French social media users talk about films such as Total Recall, the title of both a 1990 and 2012 science fiction film. Total is also the name of a French multinational oil and gas company. Some users also changed film titles to reflect the shortage: Pulp Fiction was renamed Pump Friction, The Full Monty became The Fuel Monty and Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane replaced Mad Max: Fury Road. American actor Vin Diesel's surname and his Hollywood blockbusters attracted particular attention, with people inventing several titles for his Fast and Furious series: Last and Furious, Pas Fast Mais Furious (translation: Not Fast But Furious), Immobile and Furious and Fuel Furious. Others renamed 8 Mile, a semi-biographical drama staring US rapper Eminem, 0 Mile and 8 Miles a Pied (translation: 8 Miles on Foot). American director Stanley Kubrick appeared to inspire people who posted about Fuel Metal Jacket, referring to Kubrick's 1987 film Full Metal Jacket. 2001, l'Odyssee de l'espace is the French title of Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey. But Espace is also the name of minivan built by French car manufacturer Renault. Pictures of people filling jerrycans at petrol stations led people to incorporate the term into film titles. Tom and Jerrrycan, Jerrycan Beauty and Catch Me If You Jerrycan were the result. Another obvious target was Nicolas Winding Refn's 2011 film Drive

The amnesty applies to offences committed during the political turmoil after Mr Thaksin was ousted in a coup. The lower house passed the controversial bill in the early hours of Friday. It now goes to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party has warned that the passage of the bill will trigger street protests. It did not take part in the vote, but the bill passed by 310 votes to 0. The bill's passage through the Senate is less certain, reports the BBC South East Asia correspondent Jonathan Head, as half its members are appointed. But this could happen as early as next week and would almost certainly provoke further protests. Advocates of the bill say it will draw a line under the political turmoil that resulted from the military coup in 2006 that removed Mr Thaksin from power, leaving Thailand bitterly divided. This turmoil included the occupation of Bangkok's main airport in 2008 and then two months of street protests in Bangkok in 2010 that left about 90 people - mostly civilian protesters - dead. But critics say the amnesty would allow human rights abuses to go unpunished. "The proposed amnesty would allow officials and protest leaders who have blood on their hands to go unpunished," said Brad Adams, Asia director of Human Rights Watch, on 21 October. "By whitewashing past abuses, the government denies justice to victims and tells future abusers they have little to fear." The opposition believes the bill is aimed at facilitating Mr Thaksin's return, without having to serve a jail sentence. Thaksin Shinawatra has lived in self-imposed overseas exile since being convicted of corruption in 2008, charges he says are politically motivated. The amnesty - initially limited to ordinary protesters charged over involvement in past street clashes - was suddenly expanded two weeks ago to include anyone investigated by agencies set up after the 2006 coup. It was as a result of one of those investigations that Mr Thaksin was jailed, our correspondent reports. In the wake of the coup Mr Thaksin remained popular with rural voters and both general elections since the polls have seen parties allied to him elected. His sister Yingluck Shinawatra is currently the prime minister. The opposition says it plans to challenge the legislation. "We will continue our fighting in the street until the bill is aborted. There are other avenues such as by petitioning the Constitutional Court," said Democrat Party spokesman Chavanond

The big difference compared to the existing cycle hire scheme is the bikes have no docking stations. A locking rear brake means they can be left anywhere. Gabon was selected as host on Wednesday by the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee, beating rival candidates Ghana and Algeria. "We will prepare ourselves to win the Nations Cup in 2017," said Gabon football official Jean-Felix Mba Nze. "We have decided to play and win the cup." Gabon first entered the Nations Cup in 1970 but failed to qualify for the finals until 1994. Their best results came when reaching the quarter-finals in 1996 and 2012, a tournament they co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea. During this year's Nations Cup, which also took place in Equatorial Guinea, the Panthers crashed out early after winning one and losing two of their group games. The 2017 Nations Cup will be the first time Gabon has staged the finals by itself. "Our main challenge is to organise a better competition than we did in 2012," Mba Nze, the secretary general of the Gabonese federation, told BBC Sport. "I think we won the bid because we made a good presentation and we have made efforts to improve all the stadiums, hospitals and media facilities. "We are more developed than we were for the last Nations Cup." Gabon will use two stadiums from the 2012 finals - in Libreville (capacity: 45,000) and Franceville (25,000) - while adding another two. The new venues of Port Gentil and Oyem, both of which are scheduled to be 20,000-seater stadiums, are set to be ready in August 2016, five months before the competition begins. Gabon's victory was greeted with anger by both the countries it beat. The Algerian press decried the decision, with Algeria Soir calling it a 'sporting and political defeat for Algeria' while El Watan lamented that the country's presentation was 'not sufficiently supported at political levels.' Meanwhile, the Ghanaian bid told the BBC it was 'intrigued' by the decision and asked for greater transparency in the results process, asking why the Confederation of African Football (Caf) had not made the results public. In response, Caf stated that the results of voting were not released when the host countries for the 2019, 2021 and 2023 Nations Cups were announced last September.

There are more than 100 music festivals held in the UK every year, from the likes of Glastonbury and T In The Park, to smaller events such as the Cambridge Jazz Festival and Jamie Oliver's Big Feastival. In total, 3.7 million people attend festivals every year, according to Music UK, accounting for more than 39,000 full-time jobs. However, small profit margins and a crowded market have seen some events struggle. In the wet summer of 2012, 57 festivals were forced to cancel - with the likes of Oxegen and The Big Chill shutting their doors. Although the rate of closures has slowed since then, several events - including the Temples festival in Bristol, Down To The Woods in Sedgefield and Field Day in Tunbridge Wells were called off this year; while Sonisphere failed to return from a planned hiatus in 2015. The latest research offers some reassurance to organisers though, with 88% of respondents saying they planned to attend a festival again next year - with more than half of them saying they would go to more. "It has been a challenging year for some festivals, with inclement weather conditions, general economic uncertainty following Brexit, rising expenditure and heightened security concerns," said Paul Reed, who runs the Association of Independent Festivals. "This research illustrates that the sector remains buoyant, that festival promoters are resilient and will continue to craft unforgettable experiences for audiences, who are keen to return year on year to their favourite events." A survey of employees and managers found that a quarter of new fathers took no paternity leave at all. Fewer than one in 10 took more than their two weeks statutory leave. The research by the Institute of Leadership & Management (ILM) blamed "ingrained" attitudes among employers, and concerns among new fathers that they could not afford to take leave. Last year the government announced plans to allow parents to share their maternity and paternity leave - changes are scheduled to come in April 2015. But the ILM said its research suggested the changes would have little impact if attitudes of employers were not addressed as well. "The introduction of shared parental leave is a crucial step towards enabling more women to progress into senior roles," said Charles Elvin, ILM chief executive. "Yet our research revealed cultural barriers are impeding the uptake of both two weeks statutory paternity leave and additional paternity leave." He said there remained a "cultural expectation" within organisations that women rather than men will be the ones taking extended periods away from the workplace. The report also said low levels of paternity pay discouraged new fathers, with just 9% surveyed receiving more than two weeks on full pay. Responding to the report, Frances O'Grady, secretary general of the TUC, the trade union body, said pay was the major concern. "Many dads simply can't afford to take time off, particularly as employers rarely top up their statutory pay." Currently, employed fathers are entitled to either one or two weeks' paid paternity leave, though additional leave is also given if the mother returns to work and is not claiming statutory maternity pay. Government plans involve extending this flexibility, allowing parents of newborns to exchange and share their leave. Matthew Eteson is on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, 36, and Lauren Thornton. The pair died in their sleep aboard a boat on Windermere in April 2013. Mr Eteson, 42, from Hale in Greater Manchester, denies the charge. The family had gone to the Lake District for the Easter bank holiday weekend to celebrate a friend's birthday. But on the afternoon of 1 April, Mr Eteson removed the generator from the deck and used it to power a 1kW fan heater to heat the sleeping quarter, prosecutor Mr Graham Reeds QC said. The court was told that there had been no warning to the build-up of the toxic gas because the carbon monoxide sensors had previously been disabled. Mr Reeds said the mother and daughter, both from Leyland in Lancashire, were found dead in their sleeping positions aboard the the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor cruiser Arniston, with fatal levels of carbon monoxide in their bodies. Mr Eteson, who had been sleeping in a separate compartment further away from the generator also succumbed to the effects of carbon monoxide poisoning but did awake to find the bodies. The court also heard Mr Eteson, a qualified gas fitter, had made some amendments to the generator and its exhaust, which experts subsequently deemed to be "dangerous". Ms Webster's mother, Nia Webster, had previously asked Mr Eteson about carbon monoxide sensors. He told her they were not working and his partner would unplug a portable detector whenever she was cooking. The trial continues.

NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) said blood group O negative was vital, as it could be used for patients with other blood groups in an emergency. It said O negative blood made up 12% of transfers, although only 7% of people in the UK had that blood type. Meanwhile, B negative blood is needed for ethnic groups. The NHSBT said ethnic minority groups, who were more likely to have B negative blood, were more prone to sickle cell anaemia, where misshapen blood cells could block blood vessels, causing an early death. It also said such groups were more at risk of developing thalassemia, a group of inherited blood disorders that hindered the blood's ability to carry oxygen. Only 2% of Britain's population were B negative, but hospitals had used 6% more of this blood type in the past last four weeks than the same period last year, said the NHSBT. B negative blood was useful as it could be used for both B negative and B positive patients, the organisation said. Donna Batty, donor relations manager at the NHSBT, asked donors to come forward in the "next few days". She said stocks of "these vulnerable groups" were "lower than we would like". Ms Batty added: "We are also asking donors of those blood groups who have an appointment coming up to keep it. OUP analysed more than 120,421 short stories by children aged between five and 13 years old, submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. According to the OUP, new technology is increasingly at the centre of the children's lives but how they are writing about it is changing fast. Words including email, mobile and Facebook are in decline, it said. They are being replaced by the likes of Instagram, Snapchat and emoji. And the word television has now been superseded by phone. The report also notes a sudden new arrival in children's sentences. The use of the hashtag symbol # to add an extra meaning or comment at the end of a sentence has become commonplace. #IblameTwitter #AndInstagram. Vineeta Gupta at the Oxford University Press said: "This has been a significant change in usage in this year, 2015. "Children have extended its [#] use from a simple prefix or as a search term for Twitter to an editorial device to add drama or comment." Other words on the technological endangered list are iPod, mp3 and Blackberry. In their place are iPhone, chat app WhatsApp and messaging site ooVoo. #keepup One of the most common plotlines in the short story competition was achieving sudden internet fame after posting a YouTube video. Rather than writing about watching videos, stories revolved around how many hits, shares and likes they were receiving for their own videos. #makesabetterstory Some of the most popular characters were Cinderella, footballer Lionel Messi, Snow White, Adolf Hitler and Wayne Rooney. What surprised researchers was how many children wrote using mythological characters such as Zeus, the Minotaur and Hercules. #theyloveZeus As a source for stories, World War One was common and world events in Ukraine and Syria were both popular but far behind the most frequent current affairs topic, Ebola. The search for a cure was one of the most regular plots. New words also appeared. Among the crop of new inventions were wellysaurus, gloomful and Stegasuarez, a mutant monster hybrid of a Stegosaurus and footballer Luis Suarez. #itbites The contest winners will be revealed on Friday on The Chris Evans Breakfast Show on BBC Radio 2 live from St James's Palace. The Sakurajima volcano on Japan's Kyushu island poses a "growing threat", researchers at the University of Bristol say. The volcano, located 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant, is also close to Kagoshima, a city of 600,000. Sakurajima's last deadly eruption was in 1914, when 58 people died. The Japanese archipelago, which sits on the Pacific "Ring of fire", has more than 100 volcanoes. Sakurajima regularly spews ash and there are many small explosions there each year, with the latest eruption being in February. It is closely monitored by Japanese authorities and one of two volcanoes at Level 3 out of 5 levels in Japan's volcanic warning system, which means that people are warned not to to approach the volcano. "The 1914 eruption measured about 1.5km cubed in volume," said the study's lead author Dr James Hickey, who has now joined the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines. "From our data we think it would take around 130 years for the volcano to store the same amount of magma for another eruption of a similar size- meaning we are around 25 years away." A report on the activity of the volcano was published on Tuesday and teams from Bristol University and the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre took part. Their research showed that 14 million cubic metres of magma is accumulating each year, enough to fill London's Wembley Stadium 3.5 times over. They added that the rate at which the magma is accumulating is faster than it can be expelled in its regular smaller eruptions, which led them to infer that a major eruption is likely in the next 30 years. They made these assessments based on new ways of studying and modelling the volcano's magma reservoir. Scientists say they hope these findings can help authorities plan for major eruptions. "We know that being forewarned means we are forearmed and providing essential information for local authorities can potentially help save lives if an eruption was imminent," said Dr Hickey. The Royal couple's demanding itinerary of public engagements commenced with a tour of the Giant's Causeway in County Antrim. This UNESCO World Heritage Site comprises approximately 40,000 black basalt columns that prominently extend from the sea. It marked Their Royal Highnesses' inaugural visit to Northern Ireland's most renowned tourist attraction. The causeway originated as molten rock was extruded through fissures in the earth, forming a lava plateau. Subsequently, The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh journeyed to the nearby village of Bushmills to commemorate the local soldier Robert Quigg. He was awarded the Victoria Cross for his bravery during the Battle of the Somme. Sergeant Quigg was bestowed with the nation's highest military honour for valour after venturing into active combat to search for his commanding officer. Her Majesty and His Royal Highness jointly unveiled a statue of the soldier and a commemorative stone, and his grandnephew, Leonard Quigg, also delivered a brief address. From Bushmills, the Royal couple proceeded to a reception at Portrush Golf Club, hosted by the Mayor of the Causeway Coast and Glens Borough Council. Afterwards, they embarked on a heritage steam train journey from Coleraine, County Londonderry, to the village of Bellarena. Large crowds gathered in Coleraine to greet Their Royal Highnesses upon their boarding of the five-carriage train, constructed in 1932. Accompanied by local schoolchildren, the Royal guests travelled to Bellarena, where The Queen officially inaugurated the village's new train station. The Queen and Duke of Edinburgh had previously undertaken this same journey along the historic Coleraine to Londonderry railway line in 1953, the year of Her Majesty's coronation. The original station had opened a century earlier in 1853. Earlier this year, two new railway platforms were inaugurated in Bellarena as part of a £46 million upgrade to the Coleraine to Londonderry railway line. Upon Her Majesty's arrival in the village, she unveiled a plaque marking this new development. Well-wishers lined the route, waving Union Flags and offering cheers of welcome. On Monday, the Royal visitor held an audience with Northern Ireland's First and Deputy First Ministers at Hillsborough Castle in County Down. This trip marked the third high-profile Royal visit to Northern Ireland in recent weeks, following prior appearances by The Prince of Wales and The Duchess of Cornwall, and subsequently by The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge. Their previous visit to Northern Ireland was in June 2014.

Seamer Kyle Abbott, 29, and top-order batsman Rilee Rossouw, 27, confirmed their international retirements in January. Rossouw, entering his first season in county cricket, remained evasive when asked if Cricket South Africa had forced his hand. "Maybe, maybe not," he told BBC Sport. "That story is one I'm going to tell at a different time."

These decisions stem from Kolpak contracts, which grant sportsmen from countries with associate trade agreements the same free movement rights as EU citizens. While not classed as overseas players, Kolpak signees become ineligible for international representation. Abbott and Rossouw's moves, made before Britain's EU exit, are part of a larger trend; several South Africans have signed such deals ahead of the new domestic season. Among them, all-rounder Simon Harmer has joined Essex, Stiaan van Zyl and David Wiese moved to Sussex, and fast bowler Hardus Viljoen will play for Derbyshire.

"Right now, I'm just going to enjoy life here in England," Rossouw said, preparing for his three-year Hampshire contract. "I'm enthusiastic about the season. I'm completely resolute in my decision, and I don't think that's going to change any time soon. My home is in England, and I want to be here beyond the next three years for Hampshire."

For Abbott, a four-year deal marks a return to the county he last played for as an overseas signing in 2014. "I made a lot of friends here during my last spell and it just felt like the right place for me," the right-arm pace bowler explained. Abbott had tearfully announced his international retirement after helping South Africa win a home series against Sri Lanka. However, he stated at Hampshire's pre-season media day that he had long reconciled his reasons for the decision. "I've been comfortable for a long time to be honest," he added. "I've always felt like Hampshire was a home for me. It was a very smooth transition."

Abbott and Rossouw will aim to make immediate impressions for Hampshire when they begin their County Championship Division One campaign against Yorkshire on April 7.

The persistent rift between the doctors' union and the Health Secretary deepened as Mr. Hunt accused the BMA of refusing dialogue on patient care improvements and disseminating "misinformation," a claim articulated on the BBC's Andrew Marr Show. His aim remains to revise junior doctors' contracts, which he deems "unfair." The BMA, conversely, asserted its readiness for talks, attributing the escalating strikes to Mr. Hunt's "shambolic mishandling." This protracted dispute, ignited in 2014 over pay and weekend working, has manifested in a series of strikes across England, with a 24-hour cessation of all but emergency care slated for Wednesday, commencing at 08:00 GMT.

When pressed by Marr regarding the palpable low morale among junior doctors, Mr. Hunt posited, "One of the reasons for that anger is that they were told by the BMA that their pay was going to be cut – it isn't. They were told that they were going to be asked to work longer hours – they aren't," he elaborated, emphasizing, "We are actually bringing down the hours that they work. And if you are told by your union that the health secretary wants to do these awful things – of course you are going to feel devalued."

Dr. Johann Malawana, chairman of the BMA junior doctor committee, countered by accusing Mr. Hunt of threatening to unilaterally impose a contract "roundly rejected" by junior doctors. "Junior doctors already work around the clock, seven days a week, and they do so under their existing contract," he stated, adding, "If the government want more seven-day services then, quite simply, they need more doctors, nurses and diagnostic staff, and the extra investment needed to deliver it." He further cautioned that the Health Secretary risked "alienating a generation of junior doctors and undermining the delivery of future patient care."

Echoing this sentiment, Shadow Health Secretary Heidi Alexander castigated Mr. Hunt for "insulting the intelligence" of junior doctors. "This is a group of people who are incredibly intelligent, are able to make their own minds up, have read the proposals for themselves and have followed the negotiations very carefully," she told Sky News.

The launch of what was supposed to be its flagship model has turned into a fiasco for the world's largest smartphone maker. As the South Korean company scrambled to contain the crisis, the following timeline details the developments:

**August 2:** Samsung unveiled its latest flagship model, the Galaxy Note 7, to great fanfare in New York. Packed with new features like an iris scanner, the phone garnered a positive initial response and was seen as a major rival to the upcoming iPhone 7.
**August 19:** Sales commenced in 10 markets, including South Korea and the United States, with European markets slated for October.
**August 24:** The first report of a Note 7 device "exploding" appeared in the news. Soon after, numerous incidents followed, with users posting pictures and videos of their phones overheating, exploding, or catching fire.
**September 2:** Citing faulty batteries, Samsung announced a voluntary global recall of approximately 2.5 million Note 7 phones, offering refunds or replacements.
**September 8:** The US Federal Aviation Administration and numerous airlines worldwide advised passengers not to power on or charge the Note 7 while on a plane.
**September 9:** The US Consumer Product Safety Commission urged people to stop using the phone, formalizing this with a recall on **September 15**. Meanwhile, Samsung announced it would resume Note 7 sales in South Korea on **September 28**.
**September 19:** Reports emerged of phones in China also catching fire, although Samsung stated these units used batteries from a different supplier and were not affected by the recall.
**October 1:** Samsung resumed sales of the Note 7 in South Korea. In the US, the replacement program for existing phones was in full swing.
**October 6:** The crisis deepened with the first report of a *replacement* Note 7 exhibiting the same problems. A device on a Southwest Airlines flight in the US began emitting smoke, leading to the plane's evacuation. Subsequent days brought more reports of replacement phones overheating and catching fire.
**October 9:** US carriers AT&T and T-Mobile announced they would cease issuing new Note 7 replacements and halt sales of the device.
**October 11:** Samsung announced a complete halt to all Note 7 sales pending further investigation, advising users to power down and stop using their devices.

The proposal to permanently remove thirteen fire engines, which have lain idle for two years, would reduce London's active fleet to 142 vehicles. The London Fire Brigade (LFB) argues that savings generated from this move would be reinvested to staff more Fire Rescue Units. The LFB has outlined three plans to achieve these savings, asserting that no stations will close and no firefighters will be forced from their jobs. The Brigade maintains it has continued to meet London-wide attendance time targets even with these 13 engines out of service, though it acknowledges that reinstating them would improve first-engine response times by approximately four seconds.

However, the Fire Brigades Union (FBU) vehemently opposed the plan, labeling it "dangerous and reckless" to permanently decommission the engines. An FBU spokesperson underscored their concerns, particularly in the wake of the Paris attacks, urging the LFB to reconsider. They warned that last year's closure of ten fire stations already increased response times, and removing these engines could lead to further detrimental delays. Amidst this debate, London Assembly Member Andrew Dismore presented an alternative: return the 13 fire engines to service and achieve savings by implementing alternate crewing at stations equipped with specialist appliances. These proposals are slated for discussion on December 2nd, followed by a full public consultation on how the Brigade plans to achieve its savings.

Suddenly, the news agency's feed went dark, a chilling void accompanied by a stark warning: disregard all its recent pronouncements. Only moments before, a chilling, utterly false message had declared: "Breaking: Two Explosions in the White House and Barack Obama is injured." Panic gripped US markets, sending the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeting a staggering 150 points in a flash, fueled by frantic retweets. In a scramble to contain the damage, spokesman Paul Colford announced the wire service had prudently disabled other Twitter accounts and was collaborating with the microblogging giant to untangle the breach. Adding a chilling personal dimension, AP reporter Mike Baker tweeted that the @AP hack struck less than an hour after some colleagues received an "impressively disguised" phishing email. This insidious email, masquerading as a message from a fellow AP staffer, urged recipients to click a link to a "very important" Washington Post article – a classic ruse, leading instead to a bogus login page designed to snatch staff IDs and passwords. John McCormack, 46, from Kilmarnock, drove his articulated lorry for a further 30 miles on the A9 after colliding with a car carrying three children, Perth Sheriff Court heard. McCormack admitted dangerous driving on the wrong side of the road on April 11 last year, failing to stop after an accident, and operating a vehicle in a dangerous condition. He was ordered to complete 250 hours of unpaid work and received a two-year driving ban.

Prosecutor Rebecca Kynaston detailed how motorists heading north near the House of Bruar shopping complex witnessed McCormack's lorry driving directly towards them in the southbound lane. "To their horror," she stated, "they saw the lorry coming south. He was on the wrong side of the road." These drivers narrowly avoided a collision by swerving onto the verge. However, a couple with three children in their car were not as fortunate. The lorry struck the offside of their vehicle, scraping along it with such force that, according to Ms Kynaston, "the impact was forcible and bent the truck onto the wheel." Despite the collision, McCormack continued driving for several miles before police managed to pull him over further down the A9.

Defence solicitor David Holmes told the court McCormack had no recollection of the accident, only remembering a sneezing episode just prior to the crash. Sheriff Lindsay Foulis noted that five other vehicles had to take avoiding action due to McCormack's dangerous driving. He remarked, "To go into the other carriageway of the main trunk road north, it doesn't take much imagination to work out what could have happened," highlighting the severe potential consequences.

This represents the strongest statement yet from the Philippines, whose new government under President Rodrigo Duterte has otherwise adopted a conciliatory approach, initially welcoming the 12 July decision as a "milestone" but without outright celebration. The UN-backed tribunal had unanimously ruled there was no legal basis for China's sweeping claims in the South China Sea, finding it had violated the Philippines' sovereign rights and caused "severe harm to the coral reef environment" through island-building. China, however, has vowed to ignore the binding decision, asserting the panel lacks jurisdiction and that its regional activities will remain unaffected. Despite China's insistence that the summit is "not a suitable place to discuss" the issue, the Asem gathering—the first major multilateral diplomatic event since the landmark ruling—will bring together 53 leaders from Asia and Europe, including claimant nations like Vietnam and Malaysia. Mr. Yasay, representing President Duterte, stated he would "discuss within the context of Asem's agenda the Philippines' peaceful and rules-based approach on the South China Sea and the need for parties to respect the recent decision." While the ruling, brought by the Philippines under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), is binding, the Permanent Court of Arbitration possesses no enforcement powers.

The election commission (Inec), while aspiring to announce a winner on Monday, grappled with such extensive technical hitches that voting stretched into a second day. The newly introduced electronic card readers, ostensibly to curb fraud, proved deeply problematic, notably failing to register even President Jonathan's vote. This operational debacle prompted his Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which had previously opposed the technology, to label the situation a "huge national embarrassment." Inec Chair Attahiru Jega attempted to mitigate concerns, asserting that only a "fraction" of the 150,000 card readers malfunctioned – a claim that starkly contrasts with widespread reports.

Compounding these technical woes, the election, already delayed by six weeks due to the Boko Haram insurgency, was further plagued by violence. Islamist militants attacked polling stations in the north-east, necessitating curfews and clashes with security forces. Yet, despite these grave reports, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon lauded the "determination and resilience" of Nigerian voters, declaring the process "largely peaceful and orderly." This assessment was echoed by the regional bloc Ecowas, which urged acceptance of the results, seemingly overlooking the substantial disruptions. The narrative of a smooth election was further undermined by severe tensions in southern Rivers State, where protests erupted over alleged killings of opposition workers and pervasive voting irregularities. Inec's response, expressing mere "concern" over these complaints, seemed inadequate given that one of its offices was set ablaze during the unrest.

As results trickle in, the outcome remains uncertain, but the election represents a profound challenge to the PDP's long-standing dominance since 1999. The contest between the incumbent and Gen Buhari's All Progressives Congress, alongside parallel legislative races, unfolds against a backdrop of deeply flawed execution and persistent insecurity, leaving the legitimacy of the process open

The nation's job market presented a mosaic of contrasting fortunes between January and March, celebrating a record-breaking employment rate even as whispers of a slowdown began to surface. While unemployment edged down by 2,000 to 1.69 million, holding the jobless rate steady at 5.1%, the workforce swelled to 31.58 million – a gain of 44,000 that propelled the employment rate to an unprecedented 74.2%. Yet, this triumph was tempered by a notable dip in job vacancies, which fell by 18,000 to 745,000, marking the first decline in nearly a year. This shift prompted David Freeman, a senior statistician at the ONS, to observe that the "modest" increase in employment, coupled with stagnant unemployment, hinted at a "cooling off" in the market.

Average earnings, including bonuses, managed a 2% annual rise, a slight uptick from the previous quarter, though the ONS attributed this largely to the timing of bonus payouts. Excluding these volatile payments, earnings growth actually softened, dropping from 2.2% to 2.1% year-on-year. Further complicating the picture, while April saw a modest fall of 2,400 in jobless benefit claims, revised data revealed a concerning surge of 14,700 between February and March – the largest increase since autumn 2011.

Amidst these mixed signals, Secretary of State for Work and Pensions, Stephen Crabb, championed the "record-breaking figures," celebrating more people in work than ever before and the lowest unemployment rate in a decade. However, economists offered a more circumspect view. David Kern of the British Chambers of Commerce warned that despite the employment high, the "cumulative picture" across various economic indicators suggested a "softening in economic activity." Paul Hollingsworth of Capital Economics echoed this sentiment, noting that while there were "bright spots," the overall figures were "further indication that the economic slowdown has sapped the jobs recovery of its recent vigour." Martin Beck of the EY Item Club added a pragmatic note, suggesting that with unemployment now back to its pre-crisis average, the "rapid drops" seen in 2015 were simply "unrealistic to expect" to continue indefinitely.

France is currently grappling with a nationwide fuel shortage, a direct consequence of a strike over new labor laws affecting all eight of its oil refineries. With an estimated 20% of petrol stations running dry or low on supplies, the situation has ignited a wave of creative responses on social media. On Tuesday, the hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, or "fuel shortage in a film," became France's top Twitter trend with over 5,000 tweets, showcasing users' witty takes on the crisis.

French social media users reimagined famous movie titles to reflect the scarcity. For instance, the film Total Recall became a popular reference, playing on the dual meaning of "Total"—both the film's title and the French multinational oil and gas company. Other ingenious alterations included Pulp Fiction turning into Pump Friction, The Full Monty becoming The Fuel Monty, and Mad Max: Fury Road humorously re-titled Mad Max: Fury Bicycle Lane.

American actor Vin Diesel and his Fast and Furious series proved a particular favorite for parody, spawning titles like Last and Furious, Pas Fast Mais Furious (Not Fast But Furious), Immobile and Furious, and Fuel Furious. Rapper Eminem's 8 Mile was humorously renamed 0 Mile and 8 Miles a Pied (8 Miles on Foot). Director Stanley Kubrick's films also inspired creativity: Full Metal Jacket became Fuel Metal Jacket, while 2001: A Space Odyssey (known in French as 2001, l'Odyssee de l'espace) prompted a pun on "Espace," also the name of a Renault minivan. The sight of people filling jerrycans at petrol stations inspired titles such as Tom and Jerrrycan, Jerrycan Beauty, and Catch Me If You Jerrycan. Even Nicolas Winding Refn's film Drive was rebranded Walk and Drive Pas, highlighting the shift from driving to walking.

The proposed amnesty addresses offenses committed during the political turmoil that followed Mr. Thaksin's ousting in a coup. The controversial bill was passed by the lower house in the early hours of Friday and now proceeds to the Senate. The opposition Democrat Party has cautioned that the bill's enactment will provoke widespread street protests. Though the Democrat Party abstained from the vote, the bill passed with 310 votes to none. According to BBC South East Asia correspondent Jonathan Head, its passage through the Senate is less certain, given that half of its members are appointed. Nevertheless, this could occur as early as next week, almost certainly triggering further unrest. Proponents of the bill argue it will help resolve the political turmoil stemming from the 2006 military coup that removed Mr. Thaksin from power, which has left Thailand deeply divided. This period of unrest included the 2008 occupation of Bangkok's main airport and two months of street protests in Bangkok in 2010, which resulted in approximately 90 deaths, predominantly among civilian protesters. Conversely, critics contend the amnesty would allow human rights abuses to go unpunished. Brad Adams, Asia director of Human Rights Watch, stated on October 21 that the "proposed amnesty would allow officials and protest leaders who have blood on their hands to go unpunished," adding, "By whitewashing past abuses, the government denies justice to victims and tells future abusers they have little to fear." The opposition suspects the bill is intended to facilitate Mr. Thaksin's return without requiring him to serve a jail sentence. Thaksin Shinawatra has resided in self-imposed overseas exile since his 2008 conviction for corruption, charges he maintains are politically motivated. The amnesty, initially restricted to ordinary protesters involved in past street clashes, was unexpectedly expanded two weeks prior to encompass anyone investigated by agencies established after the 2006 coup. It was one such investigation that led to Mr. Thaksin's imprisonment. Despite the coup, Mr. Thaksin retained significant popularity among rural voters, and parties allied with him have been elected in both general elections held since. His sister, Yingluck Shinawatra, currently serves as prime minister. The opposition plans to challenge the legislation. Democrat Party spokesman Chavanond Intarakomalyasut declared, "We will continue our fighting in the street until the bill is aborted. There are other avenues such as by petitioning the Constitutional Court." On Thursday, as the bill was debated, thousands of individuals protested against it outside a railway station.

Forest Enterprise Scotland plans to plant approximately 600,000 young oak trees around Loch Trool and the Cree Valley over the next few years, aiming to create a "large and vibrant habitat." Environment forester Gareth Ventress explained that recognizing a "bumper crop" of acorns prompted immediate collection planning. This effort expanded significantly, as he stated, "We also decided to get help from other staff throughout Scotland and asked them to collect acorns from other native oak woods found on the national forest estate." Community partners, including the Cree Valley Community Woodland Trust, Borders Forest Trust, and Moffat Community Woodlands, also assisted in this extensive collection to further native woodland expansion across their project areas in south Scotland. Ventress underscored the critical importance of this collaborative approach: "By combining acorns collected from across Galloway Forest Park, we increase the genetic diversity of the trees linking the remnant woodlands. This is vital for creating robust and resilient woodlands that can handle pests and diseases well into the future." Acorns are gathered by laying large felt nets across the forest floor, simplifying collection by keeping them off the soil. Once collected, they are sorted and stored. Over the next three to four years, these acorns will be germinated and grown into saplings, though many will be "graded" out as infertile. From this process, approximately 600,000 saplings are anticipated, destined to establish new oak woods and "enrich the woodland habitats" throughout Galloway Forest Park.

Mark Carney advocates for long-term green project financing in emerging markets as a means to promote global financial stability, urging Germany to prioritize this initiative during its 2017 G20 presidency. He underscored a critical imbalance: while capital theoretically should flow from advanced to emerging economies due to higher returns, the opposite trend has driven down bond yields in developed markets. Moreover, sporadic capital flows to emerging economies have proven destabilizing. Carney posits that "green finance is a major opportunity" to address this, directing capital to long-term, carbon-intensive projects and thereby enhancing stability. He noted the potential doubling of green bond issuance in 2016, though these instruments still represent a mere 1% of global financial institution holdings. Developing this "new global asset class," he argued, presents an opportunity to advance a low-carbon future, boost global investment, and spur growth. Carney also highlighted a crucial dilemma: a clear economic incentive to combat climate change may emerge only when it is too late to act effectively. He further cautioned that an overly rapid transition to a low-carbon economy could itself "materially damage financial stability." To manage this transition, Carney pressed companies to disclose the financial risks climate change poses to their business models, reiterating previous warnings about the potential for the majority of fossil fuel reserves to become unrecoverable as governments push to limit global warming.

Gene Palmer, the second prison employee detained in connection with the recent escape from Clinton Correctional Facility, faces charges including promoting prison contraband, tampering with physical evidence, and official misconduct. His arrest follows the earlier charging of Joyce Mitchell for aiding the escape of convicted killers Richard Matt and David Sweat, who utilized power tools to flee the facility. Palmer was released on bail after his court appearance. His attorney, Andrew Brockway, admitted Palmer delivered the meat containing the tools but maintained that his client was unaware of its illicit contents or the inmates' escape plans, with Palmer intending to plead not guilty. Clinton County District Attorney Andrew Wylie stated that Mitchell allegedly placed hacksaw blades and other tools inside the meat, which Palmer subsequently delivered to Matt and Sweat, who were housed in a unit where inmates could prepare their own meals. A large-scale manhunt for the two fugitives is currently concentrated on a 75 square-mile (194 sq km) area in northern New York. Evidence indicates the men spent time at a hunting cabin near the prison, leading to the presumption that they may be armed, given the region's abundant weaponry. New York State Police Major Charles Guess described the escapees as "extremely dangerous" and "cunning," questioning, "Why wouldn't they try to arm themselves immediately upon escape?"

The Conservative Party's election manifesto stipulated that a funding floor would be introduced for Wales only after a referendum on Income Tax powers had been called. The St David's Day Agreement, however, had described such a vote as an "expectation," and Labour Welsh ministers have expressed opposition to holding a referendum prior to securing a funding deal. Labour consequently accused the Conservatives of attempting to hold them "over a barrel." The Conservative manifesto explicitly states that the party would "introduce a 'funding floor' to protect Welsh relative funding and provide certainty for the Welsh Government to plan for the future, once it has called a referendum on Income Tax powers in the next Parliament." Despite this, a Welsh Conservative spokeswoman informed BBC Wales that the "St David's Day commitment we made to introduce a funding floor for Wales is firm and clear, and work is already underway at the Treasury and the Wales Office to implement this floor." She further clarified: "The funding floor for Wales is not contingent on an income tax referendum. Our UK manifesto articulates our expectation that the Welsh Assembly will hold a referendum on income tax raising powers early in the next Parliament. More detail of our ambitious plan for Wales will be announced in the Conservative Party Welsh Manifesto which will be launched later this week." On Friday, Chancellor George Osborne confirmed to BBC Wales that the proposed funding floor would range between £113 and £116 per head for every £100 spent in England, aligning with the recommendation of economist Gerry Holtham. Labour has also pledged to introduce a funding floor for the Welsh Government but has not specified a precise figure. In response to the Conservative manifesto, First Minister Carwyn Jones declared: "A vote for the Tories is a vote for a government that would cost Wales up to £300m a year. A fair funding settlement is either fair or it isn't - you can't impose conditions or try and hold the government over a barrel." The Liberal Democrats have proposed commissioning an independent review of Wales' funding arrangements, with the aim of increasing the Welsh Government's budget. Despite the sting of defeat—Hibs succumbing 10-1 on aggregate to Bayern Munich, and City bowing out 3-1 to Sweden's Eskilstuna United—a quiet triumph resonated for Scottish women's football. Anna Signeul, the national team manager, spoke with pride to BBC Scotland, hailing the "fantastic" achievement of securing two Champions League berths. This feat, she noted, underscored the tangible progress made, especially when even Euro 2017 hosts, the Netherlands, could field only one team in Europe's elite club competition. Such coveted spots, she stressed, were earned through the consistent performance of Glasgow City and the national squad.

For Hibs, their Champions League knockout debut was a baptism by fire. They faced an almost insurmountable challenge in Bayern Munich, a formidable contender boasting 26 full-time professionals, including Olympians and national team stars from across Europe. Signeul acknowledged the "unlucky" draw but framed it as an invaluable, eye-opening lesson for the young squad, a stark revelation of the pinnacle they aspire to reach. This exposure, she suggested, offered a truer measure of their potential than encounters with weaker international sides.

Glasgow City, perennial Scottish champions with nine consecutive titles, carried the weight of past glories, having reached the quarter-finals in 2014. Yet, for the second season running, their European journey ended prematurely in the round of 32. Signeul believed City had their moments against Eskilstuna, the Swedish runners-up, but ultimately found them "a little too strong," with unfortunate goals tilting the balance in both legs.

Turning to a different pitch, the week also saw questions raised over Signeul's Scottish FA colleague, men's head coach Gordon Strachan, following World Cup qualifier setbacks. Signeul, however, cautioned against direct comparisons, explaining that women's football rankings often predict results, whereas the men's game presents a more volatile and unpredictable landscape. She affirmed her belief that Strachan, who remains at the helm, continues to command the full support of his players.

The concept of shared mobility, where individuals hire transport rather than owning vehicles, is gaining traction. This trend was recently exemplified by the launch of oBike in London. Backed by significant venture capital, oBike has deployed hundreds of hire bikes across the capital, with plans to expand its fleet to thousands by the end of the summer, following large-scale operations in Southeast Asia. A key differentiator from existing cycle hire schemes is oBike's dockless system: bikes feature a locking rear brake, allowing them to be left anywhere, and are accessed via a mobile app using GPS for location. The service requires a one-off refundable deposit of £49, followed by a charge of 50p per half-hour. More companies offering similar services are anticipated to enter the market.

oBike states its intention to collaborate with existing schemes and contribute to air quality improvement and emission reduction, expressing a desire to work with Transport for London (TfL) and local councils, though such partnerships have not yet materialized. Conversely, several councils have expressed strong dissatisfaction regarding the lack of consultation and the unannounced deployment of bikes within their jurisdictions. Hackney Council, while generally supportive of cycle hire, has raised concerns about the dockless nature of oBike, citing potential obstruction of pavements and roads, and reported no prior dialogue with the company. Similarly, Hammersmith & Fulham Council voiced concerns following the unannounced appearance of approximately 400 oBike vehicles. Cllr Stephen Cowan, leader of Hammersmith & Fulham Council, stated, "We are very much in favour of cycling, but we expect companies to properly consult with us first. This launch could have been much better thought out," adding that oBike has agreed to remove the bikes deployed in the borough. This situation highlights a recurring tension in London between regulatory authorities and new technology companies, with City Hall's response being cautious. London's Walking and Cycling Commissioner, Will Norman, emphasized the need for dockless bike operators to collaborate with TfL and borough councils, stating this is essential "to ensure these bikes work for all Londoners and don't impact negatively on other cyclists, road users and pedestrians." Norman acknowledged the "real potential to make cycling more accessible for many more Londoners" but stressed the importance of schemes being "introduced in a way that suits our capital."

Gabon has been selected by the Confederation of African Football's Executive Committee as the host nation for the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations, prevailing over rival bids from Ghana and Algeria. Jean-Felix Mba Nze, a Gabonese football official, stated their resolve to win the tournament in 2017, declaring, "We have decided to play and win the cup." Gabon's inaugural entry into the Nations Cup occurred in 1970, though they did not qualify for the finals until 1994. Their most significant achievements include quarter-final appearances in 1996 and 2012, the latter a tournament they co-hosted with Equatorial Guinea. In this year's Nations Cup, also held in Equatorial Guinea, the Panthers were eliminated prematurely after securing one victory and suffering two defeats in their group stage matches. The 2017 tournament will mark Gabon's first time independently hosting the finals. Mba Nze, the secretary general of the Gabonese federation, conveyed to BBC Sport that their primary objective is to organize a superior competition compared to 2012. He attributed their successful bid to a strong presentation and substantial efforts to upgrade stadiums, hospitals, and media facilities, emphasizing their enhanced development since the previous co-hosted Nations Cup. Gabon intends to utilize two existing stadiums from the 2012 finals – in Libreville (capacity: 45,000) and Franceville (25,000) – supplementing these with two new venues. The new stadiums in Port Gentil and Oyem, each projected to accommodate 20,000 spectators, are slated for completion by August 2016, five months before the competition commences. Gabon's successful bid was met with considerable dissatisfaction by the losing nations. The Algerian press, for instance, decried the decision; Algeria Soir characterized it as a "sporting and political defeat for Algeria," while El Watan lamented insufficient political support for their country's presentation. Concurrently, the Ghanaian bid team expressed to the BBC its "intrigue" regarding the decision and called for enhanced transparency in the results process, questioning why the Confederation of African Football (CAF) had not disclosed the voting outcomes.
