Devoted festival-goers, predominantly male, annually invest an average of £581 into these ephemeral communities, often eschewing the common throng for the exclusivity of VIP passes or the comfort of enhanced camping. Their passion transcends the live spectacle, reaching into the tactile and digital realms where physical CDs and downloads still hold sway. A survey of 504 UK residents, each a veteran of at least one recent festival, unveiled these "superfans" as the very pulse of the market; commissioned by ticketing giant Eventbrite, they are the genre's evangelists, often curating experiences for their peers and igniting wider enthusiasm. Comprising a significant 28% of the festival audience, these enthusiasts are often solitary pilgrims, with over half (54%) willing to embark on their musical quests alone. Their average expenditure outstrips that of a casual attendee by £45 per event, yet this deep financial commitment masks a simmering discontent: nearly half (46%) perceive a creeping corporatization that threatens the authentic spirit of these gatherings.

Across the verdant landscapes of the UK, over a hundred music festivals unfurl each year, from the colossal legends like Glastonbury and T In The Park to the intimate charm of the Cambridge Jazz Festival or Jamie Oliver's Big Feastival. This vibrant tapestry draws 3.7 million souls annually, as reported by Music UK, underpinning over 39,000 full-time livelihoods. Yet, this effervescent scene is not without its shadows. Slim profit margins and a saturated market have cast a pall over many ventures. The deluge of 2012, for instance, saw 57 festivals tragically silenced, with titans like Oxegen and The Big Chill fading into memory. Though the torrent of cancellations has abated, the current year still witnessed the unfortunate demise of events such as Bristol's Temples festival, Down To The Woods in Sedgefield, and Field Day in Tunbridge Wells, while Sonisphere's planned 2015 return never materialized.

Amidst these challenges, the latest research offers a glimmer of hope to beleaguered organizers: a resounding 88% of respondents declared their intent to return next year, with over half pledging to attend even more events. Paul Reed, head of the Association of Independent Festivals, acknowledged a "challenging year for some festivals, with inclement weather conditions, general economic uncertainty following Brexit, rising expenditure and heightened security concerns." Yet, he affirmed the sector's "buoyant" spirit, praising resilient promoters who "continue to craft unforgettable experiences for audiences, who are keen to return year on year

Cromer was rocked by a weekend of crime, with a staggering 37 incidents recorded, including the horrific rape of a teenager. Residents quickly linked these events to a group of travelers who had arrived in town.

The situation raises serious questions about police communication. Suffolk Constabulary confirmed they had warned Norfolk Police about the group on Friday, after serving them a notice to leave Lowestoft due to previous disturbances. While Norfolk acknowledged the warning, they stated there was "no intelligence to suggest where the group was heading."

The severity of the events became starkly clear on Friday, when a woman in her late teens was raped at a bus stop near the seafront. Norfolk Police indicated this could be connected to the broader disorder. One man was arrested and later released under investigation, but no other arrests have been made.

The community's fear was palpable. On Saturday night, a BBC reporter was told by a taxi driver that "travellers are rampaging the town." Staff at The Wellington pub were forced to close after a group of 30 became "rowdy." Lee Sale, who runs an ice cream shop, described how families were frightened by "intimidating behaviour." And Ayrun Nessa, whose family owns the Masala Twist restaurant, recounted being confronted at her door by six women shouting abuse.

In response to these deeply concerning events, Cromer's Safer Neighbourhood Team is now holding police surgeries, offering residents a chance to voice their fears directly to officers. The group of up to 25 caravans, which had arrived at the Runton Road cliff-top car park on Friday, has since moved on.

The sky, a canvas vast and blue, held a sudden, chilling truth that August eve. South of Brookmans Park, a silent, white quadcopter, a fleeting specter, "flashed past" the mighty A320, a breath held, a moment frozen in time. No second to react, no space to turn, for the swift hand of fate had already moved; a collision, so narrowly averted, owed its sparing grace to chance alone. Above Potters Bar, as twilight deepened at 18:45 BST, the pilot's voice, a tremor in the air, spoke of "something" that had just soared above – a red and white enigma, striped with crimson and sapphire on its rotor arms, a mere whisper of a meter, yet holding the potential for catastrophe. For those who chart the heavens, a sacred trust is borne: to fly with wisdom, to see what flies, to guard the fragile ballet of the sky. The Air Navigation Order, a silent promise, demands that unmanned wings stay within the watchful eye, never to recklessly endanger life or property. Yet this small, striped marvel had pierced the veil, ascending beyond the permitted gaze, an unseen intruder in the A320's path. Its operator, a phantom in the ether, could not be found, leaving only the lingering echo of a near-miss, a stark reminder of the sky's delicate balance.

A recent survey found that a quarter of new fathers took absolutely no paternity leave. Even more strikingly, fewer than one in ten took more than the standard two weeks. The Institute of Leadership & Management, or ILM, pointed to two main reasons for this: deeply ingrained attitudes from employers, and new fathers worrying they simply couldn't afford the time off.

Now, the government announced plans last year to let parents share their maternity and paternity leave, with changes due in April 2015. But the ILM's research suggests these changes won't do much good unless employers' attitudes change too. Charles Elvin, ILM chief executive, called shared parental leave a "crucial step" for women advancing in their careers, but added that "cultural barriers" are still stopping fathers from taking even the basic two weeks, let alone any extra leave. Essentially, there's still this expectation in companies that women, not men, will be the ones taking long breaks from work.

What's more, the report highlighted low paternity pay as a major deterrent, with only 9% of fathers surveyed getting more than two weeks on full pay. Frances O'Grady, secretary general of the TUC, the trade union body, echoed this, saying pay is the biggest issue. She put it simply: "Many dads simply can't afford to take time off, especially since employers rarely top up their statutory pay."

Right now, employed fathers typically get one or two weeks of paid paternity leave, though they can get more if the mother goes back to work and isn't claiming maternity pay. The government's new plans aim to really expand this flexibility, letting new parents swap and share their leave. A government spokesperson said they "want shared parental leave to drive a real cultural shift" and help dads be more involved in their baby's early months. They also believe it benefits employers, by helping them "keep talented women in the workforce and have more motivated and productive staff."

Similar to last year, the Orangemen and their 13 approved bands are permitted to march past St Patrick's Church on Donegall Street in north Belfast, to the sound of a single drumbeat. This year, all music must cease 43 metres from the church, ensuring it remains beyond earshot. A planned residents' protest has also been limited to a maximum of 50 people across two locations.

The Orange Order expressed its dismay at the determination, calling the commission "merely a mouthpiece for republican propaganda, allowing them to dictate the terms of when, how and where loyal order parades are held." It further condemned "the newly invented criteria of banning music within 'earshot' of a place of worship not in use" as "as mischievous as it is absurd, and clearly put in place to further censor Protestant heritage on the supposed shared streets of Northern Ireland's capital city."

Echoing this sentiment, North Belfast DUP MP Nigel Dodds declared, "The latest determination by the Parades Commission on Donegall Street demonstrates that this is a bureaucratic monstrosity that has lost the run of itself, simply dances to the tune of republican residents, or a dangerous combination of both." He added, "It is clear from the document that the Parades Commission gave serious consideration to banning music being played outside Clifton Street Orange hall. I wish that statement was a joke but it is not."

Conversely, SDLP assembly member Alban Maginness welcomed the determination, stating, "This determination by the Parades Commission is sensible and I would hope that it sets the tone for this year's marching season." He added, "At every stage of this dispute all that the parishioners of St Patrick's and the residents of Carrick Hill have asked for is to be treated with respect."

The 34-year-old midfielder recently concluded his spell in the Indian Super League with Atletico Kolkata. Motherwell has made a contract offer to Pearson, who began his career at Fir Park. After stints with Celtic, Derby County, Bristol City, and Karela Blasters, he rejoined Motherwell for the 2015 season. Pearson is currently a free agent, having helped Kolkata achieve a fourth-place finish in the Indian league before securing the title with a play-off victory against Karela Blasters. The club is awaiting Pearson's decision regarding the contract offer.

Separately, Motherwell has recently strengthened its squad by signing winger Elliot Frear from Forest Green and acquiring Reading defender Zak Jules and Everton goalkeeper Russell Griffiths on loan. The club continues to seek further additions before the transfer window closes, with ongoing discussions yet to yield definitive responses.

The body of 24-year-old Kevin Mcleod was discovered in Wick harbour in February 1997. Initially classified as an accidental death, his family vehemently contended that the injuries on his body indicated murder. Following an appeal from the family to Chief Constable Phil Gormley, an assessment was conducted, scrutinizing "all information known" regarding the death. Police stated that this review involved tracing and interviewing individuals present in Wick on the night of Mr. Mcleod's demise who had not previously come forward. Last month, his mother, June, informed BBC Scotland that should the assessment yield "nothing new," she and her family would persist in their fight for a fresh investigation. Separately, the chief constable commissioned an assessment into the police's handling of the Mcleod family's complaints regarding the investigation since 1997. Detective Chief Superintendent Gareth Blair, head of major crime at Police Scotland, explained that this assessment was undertaken "in recognition of the continued impact" of Mr. Mcleod's death on his parents and "their desire for a conclusive outcome." Expressing ongoing sympathy for the family, he emphasized, "It is important to stress, this was not a full reinvestigation of the death itself, but a careful and considered analysis of a significant volume of information which has been recorded relating to the circumstances since 1997." Specialist officers from Police Scotland's major crime command carried out this work, which included locating and speaking to individuals who were in Wick that night and saw Kevin but had not previously presented themselves. Det Ch Supt Blair informed Mr. Mcleod's parents on Tuesday of the assessment's conclusion. He stated, "I informed Kevin's parents that having carried out this assessment there is no evidence of criminality and his death remains unexplained, leading me to determine that there is no basis on which to launch a full reinvestigation." Police Scotland appeals for any witnesses with information about Kevin's death to come forward, assuring that any new and additional information will be fully considered. The chief constable has also requested the head of professional standards to conduct a separate assessment to ensure all matters and complaints raised by the family over the years have been appropriately considered and addressed.

Matthew Eteson is currently on trial at Preston Crown Court, charged with the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster (36) and Lauren Thornton. The two individuals died in April 2013 from carbon monoxide poisoning while asleep aboard a vessel on Windermere. Mr. Eteson, 42, a resident of Hale, Greater Manchester, has entered a plea of not guilty. The court heard that the family was in the Lake District for the Easter bank holiday weekend to celebrate a friend's birthday. Prosecutor Mr. Graham Reeds QC stated that on the afternoon of April 1st, Mr. Eteson relocated the generator from the vessel's deck and used it to power a 1kW fan heater, intended for heating the sleeping cabin. Evidence presented indicated an absence of warning regarding the accumulation of the toxic gas, as the onboard carbon monoxide sensors had reportedly been disabled. Mr. Reeds further detailed that the mother and daughter, both from Leyland, Lancashire, were discovered deceased in their sleeping positions aboard the second-hand Bayliner 285 motor cruiser 'Arniston,' exhibiting fatal levels of carbon monoxide in their systems. Mr. Eteson, who had been sleeping in a separate compartment further from the generator, also suffered from carbon monoxide poisoning but subsequently awoke to find the bodies. Furthermore, the court was informed that Mr. Eteson, a qualified gas fitter, had made modifications to the generator and its exhaust system that experts subsequently deemed "dangerous." Prior to the incident, Ms. Webster's mother, Nia Webster, had reportedly inquired with Mr. Eteson about the carbon monoxide sensors; he informed her they were inoperable

NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) has emphasized the critical importance of O negative blood, which can be universally transfused in emergency situations. The organization noted that O negative blood accounts for 12% of transfusions, despite only 7% of the UK population possessing this blood type. Furthermore, B negative blood is particularly required by certain ethnic minority communities. NHSBT explained that these groups, who disproportionately possess B negative blood, are at a higher risk of developing sickle cell anaemia—a condition characterized by misshapen red blood cells that can obstruct blood vessels, potentially leading to premature mortality. Additionally, these groups are more susceptible to thalassemia, a group of inherited blood disorders that impair the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity. Despite B negative blood comprising only 2% of the British population, hospitals have utilized 6% more of this blood type over the past four weeks compared to the corresponding period last year, NHSBT reported. The organization clarified that B negative blood is valuable due to its compatibility with both B negative and B positive patients.

Donna Batty, Donor Relations Manager at NHSBT, urged donors to present themselves in the coming days. She explained that reserves of these critical blood types are currently below optimal levels. Ms. Batty further requested that donors of these blood groups with scheduled appointments honor their commitments, stating, "We trust that our dedicated donors will respond to this appeal, and we ask for their understanding should there be slightly extended waiting times during donation sessions as a consequence."

Overall, 4% of the UK's population currently donates blood. Jon Latham, Assistant Director of Marketing at NHSBT, stated that ideally, the organization seeks to attract new donors. He emphasized that a broader database of willing donors facilitates the ability to solicit contributions during periods of increased demand for specific blood types. Individuals uncertain of their blood type can ascertain this information post-donation, NHSBT advised. Those interested in donating are encouraged to contact NHSBT on 0300 123 23 23.

Minister Stephen Farry's decision to strip St Mary's University College, a small institution with fewer than 1,000 students and an annual income of £4.7m, of its £1.1m special premium payment has plunged the institution into crisis. This vital funding previously compensated the college for its unique small scale and specialist status. Compounded by broader Department of Employment and Learning (DEL) cuts, the move initially threatened a devastating 31% reduction in St Mary's budget. Although a newly revealed £32m injection into the DEL's overall budget slightly mitigates the blow, the college still projects a daunting 26.5% budget cut. Principal Prof. Peter Finn labels this figure "far too challenging," vehemently accusing Farry of a "blatantly opportunistic" decision. Finn believes the Minister aims to coerce the college into accepting one of his proposed solutions for streamlining teacher training in Northern Ireland, none of which preserve St Mary's cherished autonomy. Despite the college's fierce determination to retain its distinct character and Catholic ethos, Prof. Finn expresses personal openness to "very deep sharing" among teacher training institutions, potentially involving student exchanges or shared teaching. He strongly refutes the argument that these small-scale and specialist premia are unique to Northern Ireland and thus expendable. While similar payments were indeed cut in England, Finn highlights that those institutions were simultaneously granted the freedom to charge significantly higher tuition fees and were not restricted in student intake – liberties explicitly denied to St Mary's. Parallel to St Mary's struggle, Stranmillis University College, which primarily trains teachers for non-Catholic schools, faces analogous challenges. Its protracted negotiations since 2008 to merge with Queen's University have met opposition and remain unapproved, with the proposed funding cuts and premium removal poised to similarly impact its future.

A significant investment, backed by nearly £15 million from the Welsh government, is set to commence production in late 2018. Economy Minister Edwina Hart stated that the agreement would "safeguard more than 750 skilled Welsh jobs for many years," emphasizing the government's active pursuit of this investment for Wales amidst "stiff global competitiveness." Hart further remarked, "Ford's decision to manufacture its new innovative engine here in Wales is a tribute to the reputation of the local management team and the quality and loyalty of the Welsh workforce." Established in 1980, the Ford Bridgend plant has historically contended with fierce competition, securing successive investments exceeding £2.8 billion. Ford estimates its presence supports approximately 10,000 jobs across South Wales, with 1,860 directly employed at the Bridgend facility. The design and development of the new fuel-efficient engine range involved collaborative efforts from technicians in Essex and Germany. A letter from Ford to its workforce, observed by the BBC in June, indicated that securing this investment necessitated adjustments to working conditions at Bridgend to enhance the plant's competitiveness. This development is particularly beneficial for Bridgend's employees, as the new production is slated to commence in 2018, coinciding with the conclusion of Jaguar Land Rover engine manufacturing at the site, thereby safeguarding hundreds of jobs that might otherwise have been at risk. Earlier this year, however, 200 fixed-contract workers were made redundant at Ford Bridgend following the cessation of Volvo engine manufacturing. Welsh Conservative shadow economy minister William Graham interpreted Friday's announcement as a signal of "confidence in the UK government's efforts to rebuild the economy." However, concerns persist that this new investment may result in Bridgend producing only a third of its current engine volume. Questions have also been raised regarding the Welsh government's £15 million contribution to a multinational company's investment in its own plant. This funding, however, is contextualized by Bridgend's competition against three other European Ford plants, each supported by government financial aid as a standard practice, as the intensely competitive international automotive industry often necessitates such backing to prevent companies from relocating production.

S4C, which draws the majority of its revenue from the licence fee, faces an uncertain future as UK ministers announce a comprehensive review of the BBC. Monmouth MP David Davies champions S4C as a "special case," vital for promoting the Welsh language, even as ministers demand it achieve cost savings akin to the BBC. On Thursday, Labour voiced concerns that impending cuts to the BBC's budget could imperil S4C's operations. However, Culture Secretary John Whittingdale reassured MPs of a commitment to the channel "within the next couple of years," anticipating imminent discussions with its leadership. Speaking on BBC Radio Cymru's Rhaglen Dylan Jones on Friday, Mr. Davies underscored the government's recognition of S4C's profound significance, not merely as a broadcaster, but as a cornerstone for the Welsh language's future. He further intimated that the Welsh Affairs Committee, under his chairmanship, might launch an inquiry into broadcasting, encompassing S4C. Reaffirming his personal conviction, Davies asserted, "S4C is a special case because of its role in promoting the Welsh language, and I believe its continued existence is more critical than any other BBC channel." Since 2010, S4C has endured significant funding reductions, and intends to highlight the "uniqueness" of its service and its "cultural and economic value and importance" in forthcoming ministerial talks. Concurrently, a green paper on the BBC's future, published Thursday, observed a decline in audience reach across indigenous language services, particularly in Wales, noting that the elevated hourly cost of Welsh-language radio programming compared to its English counterpart "raises concerns about value for money."

Scotland's job market roared to life in April, with a remarkable surge in both permanent and temporary roles. Permanent appointments soared for the third consecutive month, marking the fastest expansion in nearly two years and bucking a broader UK slowdown. Temporary placements, too, saw their steepest rise since August 2014, with demand for contract staff hitting a nearly decade-high peak. Across key sectors, the hunger for talent was palpable: IT, nursing/medical/care, and hospitality led the charge for permanent roles, with similar pressures felt in temporary staffing for healthcare, tech, and engineering/construction. This fierce competition translated into tangible gains, with average permanent salaries climbing sharply and temporary pay rising at its fastest rate in a year.

Yet, amidst this vibrant resurgence, a formidable challenge cast a shadow: a rapidly shrinking pool of available candidates. Employers, grappling to secure essential skills, found themselves increasingly stymied. The availability of permanent staff plummeted to a nine-month low, while the decline in temporary candidates reached its quickest pace in almost two years. Kevin Green, REC chief executive, lauded the "resurgence" of the Scottish market, noting "a lot to feel good about north of the border." However, he quickly tempered this optimism, underscoring that "declining candidate availability is a threat to this success," as businesses struggle to secure the expertise they desperately need. His message to the incoming government was clear: to sustain this economic momentum, urgent investment in UK jobseekers and a safeguarded pathway for international talent are paramount. An agile immigration system, he stressed, is not merely beneficial but vital to reflect and adapt to the nation's evolving labour market demands.

Envoy Sigrid Kaag commented as Syria appeared to miss a Sunday deadline for the removal of its chemical arsenal from the country. The complete destruction of Syria's chemical weapons stockpile is scheduled for June 30. The Russian-US agreement to dismantle Syria's arsenal was brokered last year, following a sarin rocket attack near Damascus that claimed hundreds of lives.

The multinational mission tasked with the elimination of these weapons is overseen by the UN Security Council and the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW). While the UN has set a deadline of June 30 for the complete destruction of Syria's chemical weapons, Damascus had previously committed to removing its stockpile by April 27, having already missed several earlier deadlines.

Ms. Kaag, head of the OPCW-UN Joint Mission, emphasized the urgency, telling the BBC, "The biggest bulk of the chemical weapons material is removed but not yet destroyed and that counts towards the 30 June deadline. That's why it's so important to get the remainder of the chemical weapons material that is still in one site." She further noted the UN's concern regarding recent reports alleging the use of chlorine gas as a weapon by Syrian forces. Chlorine was not among the substances covered by the agreement, which is widely credited with averting US military action against the Syrian government. Damascus has, however, denied these allegations of chlorine gas use.

According to the OPCW, most of Syria's chemical weapon substances exist as precursor materials that only become highly toxic warfare agents when combined. Ms. Kaag affirmed that the facilities required to produce, prepare, and launch a chemical weapons attack have been dismantled. She concluded by stating, "What remains are the elements of a chemical weapon, but the chemical weapons programme of Syria, as per the current declaration to the OPCW under the Chemical Weapons Convention is no longer in existence."

Kim Little, a Seattle Reign player, has won the BBC World Service award, becoming its second recipient after topping a supporters' poll. She prevailed over a strong shortlist that included Gaelle Enganamouit, Amandine Henry, Carli Lloyd, and Becky Sauerbrunn. "I'm surprised to win, I'm extremely humbled to win," said the 25-year-old Little, who received the award at her club's training ground on Tuesday, adding, "Women's football is in a great place. Hopefully it will progress further." Mary Hockaday, Controller of BBC World Service English, acknowledged her talent, noting, "It's been another outstanding year for women's football and Kim's talent shines through on the pitch." In 2015, Little was Seattle's leading scorer, and second overall in America's National Women's Soccer League, with 10 goals, helping the Reign top the league. That year, she also played on loan at Melbourne City. The former Hibernian and Arsenal Ladies star, a five-time title winner with the Gunners, boasts 115 appearances for Scotland, scoring 46 goals. The Aberdeen-born player helped Great Britain reach the quarter-finals at the London Olympics in 2012 and has a history of individual accolades, including the FA's Women's Player of the Year in 2010 and the inaugural PFA Women's Players' Player of the Year award in 2013. Scotland coach Anna Signeul lauded her, stating, "She's a player that has almost everything. She's quick, her balance and movement on the pitch is fantastic. She has brilliant technique; there are few things she can't do. She's a role model, perfect in everything she does on and off the pitch, and I think it will take a long time before Scotland gets another player like this."

Fraser, ranked 90th in the world, unfurled a masterful performance, sinking nine birdies to conclude his round with an eight-under-par 63, establishing a three-shot lead over the field. A significant shadow, however, had already fallen over the greens, as more than half of the world's top ten male golfers had withdrawn from Rio 2016, their absence attributed to concerns over the Zika virus. Amidst this backdrop, the Games witnessed a moment of pure sporting magic: Briton Justin Rose, then among a quintet at four under, etched his name into history with the first-ever Olympic hole-in-one, a perfect strike on the par-three fourth. Rose, reflecting on the improbable feat, mused, "There is always an element of luck, but you could chalk it up as a good hole-in-one." He contrasted it with a previous ace that yielded a car, declaring this moment "definitely better, better bragging rights." The unique triumph, he felt, was unassailable: "When you are the first to do something no one can take that away from you. That was definitely a cool moment." Elsewhere on the leaderboard, the recently crowned Open champion, Henrik Stenson, shared second place with Canada's Graham Delaet, both poised at five under. Rose himself found company in a cluster of five men tied for fourth at four under, a distinguished group including Belgium's Thomas Pieters, France's Gregory Bourdy, Germany's Alex Cejka, and Spain's Rafael Cabrera Bello. Danny Willett, the April victor of the Masters, a title last claimed by a Briton two decades prior, concluded his round at an even par 71. The second round is slated to commence on Friday at 11:30 BST,

A commemorative rugby match will be held on 24 January 2015 at Olney Rugby Club, featuring players from the East Midlands region against The 1st Battalion of the Yorkshire Regiment, while Olney Ladies will face the Army Women's XV. This event honors a charity game played on 30 January 1915, which was organized by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs to recruit sportsmen for his World War One battalion.

Mobbs, born in Northampton in 1882, began his rugby career in Olney before becoming captain of Northampton Rugby Football Club in 1907. He earned seven England caps, scoring a try on his 1909 debut against Australia. Despite retiring from rugby in 1913 at age 30, Mobbs was refused an officer's commission at the outbreak of war due to his age, joining instead as a private. He actively encouraged enlistment, speaking at events such as a Northampton Saints game, and is credited with persuading over 200 men to join. The 1915 international match reportedly inspired hundreds to enlist in his Sportsman's Battalion, which formed a significant part of the 7th Battalion of the Northamptonshire Regiment. Among these recruits were 16 Olney players who later died during the war. Mobbs himself rose from private to battalion commander, fighting in Loos, Somme, Arras, and Messines. He was twice Mentioned in Despatches and awarded the Distinguished Service Order, before being killed on 31 July 1917 while charging a German machine gun during the Battle of Passchendaele.

Members of Mobbs's family, including his great-nephew, also named Edgar Mobbs, are scheduled to attend the upcoming game. He quoted MP Ryland Adkins, who stated, "'Northamptonshire in time of peace produced no finer sportsman and in time of war no finer soldier'." Jarlath McElroy, Chairman of Olney Rugby Club, described Mr. Mobbs as a "sporting and war hero." Funds raised at the event will benefit the Soldiers' and Sailors' Families Association military charity.

The new charity will manage the National Heritage Collection, which includes Stonehenge and Dover Castle. The government currently contributes £22m annually towards the collection. The charity aims to eventually become self-sufficient, while other powers such as listing buildings will remain government funded. A new official body, with the working name of the National Heritage Protection Service, will also advise on planning. The new charity will retain the name English Heritage, and the 420 sites in the National Heritage Collection, including London's Kenwood House and Charles Darwin's home in Kent, will remain in public ownership. Government funding for the charity will be tapered down from 2015, eventually ceasing, which is intended to provide greater freedom for generating income from commercial activities and philanthropic donations. Some of the £80m awarded by the government will support the charity's establishment, aiming for full operation by March 2015. This announcement coincided with the government's statement regarding cuts of up to 5% in funding for museums and the arts in the 2015-2016 Spending Review.

On May 22nd, in the quiet intimacy of her Dunoon home, 51-year-old Dorothy Beattie was brutally strangled by Christopher Kelly, her 40-year-old friend. The High Court in Glasgow later revealed the catalyst: an alleged jibe about Kelly's children, spiraling into a fatal confrontation. Their bond, once professional as Kelly served as a support worker for Ms. Beattie—a divorced mother grappling with various medical conditions, including seizures—had blossomed into friendship, their lives intertwined by frequent social gatherings. Yet, that bond shattered when, in her own home, the social care graduate launched a violent assault after she allegedly uttered "derogatory" remarks about his children. He seized Ms. Beattie, his hands closing around her throat, strangling her until life faded, then fled the scene. In a chilling act of post-mortem intimacy, he later returned to find her lifeless, sitting beside her body before carefully moving it to her bed, then vanishing once more into the night. His flight from the scene was compounded by a cold act of betrayal: using Ms. Beattie's bank card, he stole £300 from her account before boarding a train to Edinburgh. Three agonizing days later, on May 25th, it was her daughter, frantic from unanswered calls, who stumbled upon the horrific discovery of her mother's body. Kelly, meanwhile, endured days sleeping rough in Edinburgh, his guilt festering, until May 28th, when he finally sought out a GP surgery and unburdened himself of the confession. To the doctor, he uttered the chilling words, "Something bad has happened... I think I killed her." His fragmented recollection painted a harrowing picture: "I remember fighting and grabbing her around the neck. I blacked out and don't remember anything until I suddenly became aware she was dead. I carried her body to the bed and left the house. I've not been back since." He also clung to the fragile memory of their past, stating, "We're just pals - I had been her support worker," a desperate echo of their shattered relationship. Police were summoned, and to them, Kelly confessed the preceding days had been "torture," a torment of his own making. The court revealed the brutal truth

On April 3, just after 15:30 BST, a train traveling from Penzance to Exeter collided with a stationary train on platform six, injuring approximately 35 people. Initial findings from the Rail Accident Investigation Branch (RAIB) revealed the incident stemmed from the signaller's belief that there was sufficient space for both trains on the platform. The RAIB report elaborated that while "permissive working"—allowing trains to share a platform—is permitted for passenger trains on platform six, the signaller's estimate of available space proved inaccurate, despite visibility of the stationary train's rear from the signal box.

One train had been diverted to platform six due to passenger lift closures for maintenance on alternative platforms. As the moving train approached Plymouth, it accelerated to approximately 21 mph before navigating a tight, left-hand curve. The driver then observed the stationary train's rear on platform six, noting its unexpected proximity to the platform's west end. The investigation report detailed that the driver, having confirmed the train's route and realizing a collision was imminent, applied the emergency brake. The collision, occurring at approximately 15 mph, followed roughly three seconds later. Many passengers, standing in preparation to disembark, were consequently thrown against the train's interior fixtures and onto the floor.

Uganda's recent presidential election culminated in the incumbent, 71-year-old Yoweri Museveni, officially securing 60.75% of the vote against challenger Kizza Besigye's 35%, according to the election commission. This purported victory, however, has been widely contested. Besigye, currently under house arrest, vehemently denounced the results as a "sham," declaring the process the "most fraudulent" in Uganda's history and urging international rejection. These claims are substantially corroborated by EU observers, who cited an "intimidating atmosphere" orchestrated by the governing party and noted how the National Resistance Movement's "domination of the political landscape distorted the fairness of the campaign." The election itself was marred by sporadic violence, pervasive allegations of vote rigging, and the systematic blocking of social media and messaging apps. The house arrest of Besigye, initiated on suspicion of intending to announce parallel results, along with similar reports concerning former Prime Minister Amama Mbabazi, underscores a clear pattern of suppressing key opposition figures. This marked the fourth contest between Museveni and Besigye, former allies from Museveni's guerrilla days, who seized power in 1986. While initially credited with restoring stability, critics argue Museveni's long tenure has increasingly devolved into authoritarianism, with these recent electoral tactics serving as a stark illustration of his government's tightening grip on power.

The retailer's ambitious plans for a 72,000 sq m regional centre in Chippenham promise a thousand new jobs and an annual £31 million boost to the local economy. Yet, this vision for the town, which awaits discussion by Wiltshire Council, has ignited a fierce debate. Thousands of local residents have signed opposing petitions, and among the five parliamentary candidates vying for the area's MP seat, opinions are sharply divided, as revealed during a BBC Wiltshire election debate. Conservative candidate Michelle Donelan acknowledged the project's potential but deemed the recently concluded consultation "inadequate for something that is dramatically going to change the town forever." Labour's Andy Newman, conversely, voiced strong support, citing assurances of 700 permanent skilled jobs and a positive impact on local wages. In stark contrast, Green Party candidate Tina Johnston vehemently opposed the development, dismissing the job creation figures as unrealistic. The remaining two candidates, while open to the development itself, harbored serious reservations about its placement. UKIP's Julia Reid suggested a site closer to the motorway, further from the town centre, to mitigate the threat to existing local businesses. Similarly, Liberal Democrat Duncan Hames welcomed the prospect of jobs but questioned the suitability of the proposed location.

A 31-year-old individual reported via social media an incident in which she was allegedly refused service by a licensed taxi driver, who reportedly told her to "find an immigrant" for transportation; this purported altercation occurred shortly after she had publicly apologized "on behalf of my country" concerning the conditions at the Calais migrant camp. She further articulated that this interaction offered a "tiny glimpse" into the experience of discrimination, particularly from her position of "having lived a life of privilege," though her account has been met with skepticism, with some social media users challenging its veracity and requesting the taxi's registration details. She countered these challenges by characterizing them as "victim shaming" and explaining her inability to record the details due to being fully occupied with her children. The Licensed Taxi Drivers' Association (LTDA), representing approximately 5,500 black cab drivers in London, unequivocally condemned abusive behaviour and urged Transport for London to initiate an investigation into the claims; Steve McNamara, the LTDA's General Secretary, affirmed that while the driver's membership status remained unconfirmed, the association "takes any allegation such as this extremely seriously" and "would condemn any cabbie who treats anyone with such disrespect and uses abusive language," emphasizing that such "appalling behaviour" jeopardizes a driver's license. Earlier that month, during an appearance on the BBC's Victoria Derbyshire programme, the individual became visibly emotional during an encounter with Shamsher Sherin, a 13-year-old Afghan boy from the migrant camp, to whom she expressed profound apologies "on behalf of my country," asserting that "the English in particular" had, at various junctures, placed the boy in peril, citing actions such as bombing his country, leaving him vulnerable to the Taliban, and compelling him to risk his life to enter the UK.

Swansea City has secured the services of 25-year-old World Cup runner-up Federico Fernandez for an undisclosed fee, understood to be in the region of £8m. The Argentine centre-back, who featured in four of his nation's World Cup final campaign matches, arrives on a four-year contract and is expected to join the squad for Saturday's home opener against Burnley, pending international clearance.

Fernandez's arrival fills the void left by Chico Flores, 27, following his move to Qatar. The defender expressed palpable delight at the opportunity, revealing his long-held ambition: "It has always been my dream to play in the Premier League – it is the best in the world – and I'm immensely grateful to Swansea for giving me this opportunity." He further shared that he had sought counsel from former teammates, Michu and Jordi Amat. "I asked Michu and Jordi Amat about the club. I trained with Michu at Napoli, and while on loan at Getafe [in 2013], I played with Alvaro Vazquez, who is very good friends with Jordi. So I've spoken to them too," he explained. "Michu told me it is a family club and the city is very relaxed. He said I was joining a very good club. All I've heard are good things about Swansea."

Having only recently returned to training after his World Cup exertions, Fernandez's readiness for Saturday's clash against Burnley, which marks Swansea's first home Premier League match after their impressive 2-1 away victory at Manchester United, remains uncertain.

Manager Garry Monk lauded the acquisition, highlighting Fernandez's pedigree. "He brings that pedigree where he's been playing for Napoli at the top level and for Argentina at the World Cup," Monk stated. "The age that he's at is very good for us and the type of player that he is. He's a good size, a very good footballer and someone who will suit Swansea City. The type of players that we try and identify to come in here are ones that add quality to the squad, and he definitely will do that."

New CCTV footage of Charlene Downes, 14, who was last seen in Blackpool town centre, has been discovered during a review of materials. Her body has never been found.

The footage, released on the anniversary of Charlene's 2003 disappearance as part of the force's longest-running murder investigation, shows her with her sister Rebecca on Bank Hey Street at approximately 15:25 GMT on November 1, 2003, walking towards the Coral Island amusement arcade. Police confirmed the clothes Charlene is wearing are the same as those she wore when she vanished after returning to Blackpool town centre later that evening, which marked her last known sighting.

Charlene's mother, Karen Downes, expressed her "disgust" that the footage was only found after years of investigation into the unsolved case. She stated, "What I can't fathom is why this [the footage] was never found in the previous investigation. This is the bit I'm absolutely disgusted with." She added, "At the same time I'm happy with the footage and now hopefully they [the detectives] can move forward and we can get some answers. I want closure now... We can't move on with our lives and it's just terrible."

Lancashire Police stated it "understood" Ms Downes' views. Det Ch Insp Richard McCutcheon commented, "I can understand [the family's] views. We have just found the images and that's why we are publishing them now."

No one has been convicted in connection with Charlene's death. Det Supt Andy Webster indicated that officers are investigating potential links between Charlene's disappearance and the "wider issue of child sexual exploitation" in Blackpool. He added, "We have identified a number of people who could potentially be victims and offenders and we will be seeking to make arrests and prosecute abusers in the near future."

In 2008, a man was acquitted of Charlene's murder after a judge cited "grave doubts" about evidence during his second trial, following a hung jury in the first. A year later, the Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) concluded that police evidence-gathering errors contributed to the collapse of the retrial. The IPCC identified "strategic and tactical failure in the management of the material," leading to the discipline of several officers, one of whom was ordered to resign in 2011. This resignation order was subsequently overturned by a 2012 Police Arbitration Tribunal.

Julia Knight, 56, has entered a plea of not guilty to the attempted murder of Irene Robson, 81, at Horton Hospital in Banbury in October 2014, and to causing grievous bodily harm with intent, though she admits administering insulin to Ms. Robson. Testifying at Oxford Crown Court, Knight stated her actions were motivated by a desire to prevent her own discharge from the hospital and to ensure her mother remained in institutional care. She expressed profound remorse for her actions, acknowledging their detrimental nature and regretting them. Knight further admitted to making false statements to the police during initial questioning in January, attributing her denials to a realization of the gravity of the situation and a sense of shame. The court heard evidence that she had forged a prescription for insulin, which she collected from a Sainsbury's store. Prosecutor John Price QC asserted that Knight intended to administer a lethal dose to Ms. Robson before leaving the hospital. When questioned on her use of a potentially fatal substance, Knight maintained that she never intended her mother's death. The court was also informed that Knight had attempted suicide in 2006 by injecting herself with insulin. While Ms. Robson died in September, the jury was previously instructed that her death bore no relevance to the issues under consideration in the present trial.

South Korea achieved a significant milestone in its space program as the Korea Space Launch Vehicle-1 (KSLV-1), also known as Naro, successfully blasted off from the Naro Space Center at 16:00 (07:00 GMT). Officials quickly confirmed that the 140-tonne rocket, built in partnership with Russia, had reached its target altitude and deployed its Science and Technology Satellite-2C, designed to collect crucial climate data. Science Minister Lee Ju-ho proudly announced that, after analyzing various data, the satellite was in its designated orbit, having detached 540 seconds after launch.

This triumph at the center, located 480km (298 miles) south of Seoul, marked a hard-won victory for South Korea. Previous domestic launch attempts in 2009 and 2010 had ended in failure—one with a satellite failing to detach, the other with the rocket exploding shortly after take-off—and this latest effort had already faced two technical postponements. Minister Lee hailed the success, declaring, "We now have leapt up a step to become a space-power nation." He emphasized that this "overwhelming moment" would serve as a "strong, dynamic force" to propel an independent national space program, acknowledging that while South Korea already operates satellites, they were previously launched from foreign soil.

The successful launch arrived weeks after North Korea had placed its own satellite into orbit using a three-stage rocket, an act that drew widespread international criticism and led to extended UN sanctions against Pyongyang for what was deemed a banned test of missile technology. North Korea's launch on December 12th had heightened pressure on Seoul and was followed by Pyongyang's announcement of plans for a "high-level nuclear test" and more long-range rocket launches, prompting international calls against such actions.

Operators now await contact with the Science and Technology Satellite-2C's ground station at 05:00 on Thursday for final confirmation of the mission's full success.

The chairman of the Premier League club, Assem Allam, threatened to resign within 24 hours if his proposed name change was rejected, a fate sealed by the Football Association's decision in April. "When I say something, I mean it," declared the 75-year-old Egyptian on Thursday, reinforcing his resolve. He further revealed that, true to his word, the club had been put up for sale a mere 22 hours after the FA's decision five months prior.

Allam confirmed an appeal against the name change rejection was being lodged with the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Recalling his earlier pronouncements, he reiterated: "We stated earlier this year that the club would be for sale should our attempt to globally promote Hull Tigers as a brand name and as a playing name be blocked." He then underscored his swift action: "As a consequence of the FA decision on 9 April, I announced on 10 April, within 22 hours, that Hull City is for sale."

Allam, who assumed control of the club in December 2010, faced questions regarding his course of action if a buyer remained elusive and the legal appeal was ultimately dismissed. His response was unequivocal: "I will give it away. Out means I'm out. Have I ever said anything and gone back on it?" Despite his dramatic pronouncements, Allam affirmed that he and his son, Ehab, the club's acting chief executive, would maintain their commitment to the club in the interim. He outlined his immediate future with stark simplicity: "If the appeal comes first, ok, no harm done. If the sale comes first - sold." He remained vague regarding interest from potential buyers, yet hinted at the possibility of remaining at the helm should the appeal prove successful.

Nineteen-year-old Scot Higgins, whose journey began in Celtic's storied youth ranks, now carries the echoes of four senior appearances for Dundee last season. Beside him stands Alan Power, 29, a former Republic of Ireland Under-21, who leaves behind the thunder of over 250 league appearances for English League Two side Lincoln City. Both have now pledged two years to the heart of Rugby Park, though Power's path awaits final clearance.

"It feels good to be here," Higgins declared, a whisper of ambition on Kilmarnock's digital heart, "as it's a club that's definitely going in the right direction." Manager Lee McCulloch sees in Higgins a reflection of Kilmarnock's soul, a commitment to nurturing young talent. "He emerged from Celtic's academy," McCulloch noted, "a forge of impressive young players. His taste of senior football at Dundee last season will only ripen with time, a harvest for this club."

Power, in turn, spoke of the town's whispers, the club's deep history, and a manager's vivid visions that made the decision an effortless tide. "I can't wait to get started," he affirmed. England's back row has been significantly impacted by injuries, with James Haskell, Sam Jones, Mike Williams, and the versatile Maro Itoje all ruled out.

In other squad developments, Jones highlighted the progress of 24-year-old Harrison, who, after a brief 30-minute appearance against Australia in Sydney, has diligently worked on his game. Jones noted Harrison's "exceptional" recent performance against Castres, positioning him as potentially the "number one choice" for open-side flanker.

Regarding selection, Jones also discussed Tom Wood, who was recalled to the squad. Previously, Jones had described Wood's post-Rugby World Cup performances as "distinctly average," but now indicates that the flanker has a "great chance" of selection this autumn. Jones cited Wood's improved work-rate, ball-carrying impact, lineout skills, and breakdown work as reasons for his current "above average" status, deeming these improvements crucial for his selection prospects.

The 33-man squad includes six uncapped players, though Jones has downplayed their immediate selection prospects. He cautioned against debuting uncapped players against South Africa on November 12, suggesting it might not be the "right game" for such an introduction.

England is scheduled to travel to Portugal for a training camp on Sunday. The team aims to prevent a recurrence of the injury issues that plagued their previous gathering in Brighton, which resulted in three serious player injuries. Jones affirmed the team's commitment to ensuring an "injury-free camp" while simultaneously emphasizing the necessity of intense training to adequately prepare for international rugby.

Usurping the names of revered organisations like NASA and the Environmental Protection Agency, a powerful new wave of resistance accounts is directly confronting the president, whose dismissive declaration of climate change as a 'hoax' has ignited a desperate digital uprising. The @RogueNASA account boldly proclaims itself the "unofficial 'Resistance' team of NASA," declaring, "Not an official NASA account. Not managed by gov't employees. Come for the facts, stay for the snark" – a stark testament to its revolutionary intent. When BBC News reached out to the rogue Environmental Protection Agency account, @ActualEPAFacts, they revealed a profound sense of duty, compelled to ensure "factual information about climate change and other scientific research continues to be shared during the Trump administration" – a vital counter-narrative against official suppression. These purported EPA employees described a chilling gagging order that silenced their research, pushing them to this clandestine activism. Alarming media reports had already painted a grim picture of the Trump administration's efforts to muzzle government agencies, including the EPA, from public communication, a reality underscored by the official EPA Twitter account's telling silence since January 19th, the eve of Mr. Trump's inauguration. @ActualEPAFacts expressed astonishment at the overwhelming surge of support, with over 90,000 followers, yet admitted to feeling exposed by their courageous actions. This wave of defiance is not isolated; other rogue accounts have also garnered massive followings. @RogueNasa swiftly attracted over 370,000 followers within days, while @AltNatParkSer, the rogue National Park Service account, became a phenomenon, amassing over a million followers with fewer than 300 tweets – a staggering indicator of widespread disquiet. Similar rogue accounts for the US Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention have emerged, united by a common cry of "resistance," blending crucial scientific information with searing critiques of Mr. Trump. Many behind these clandestine operations claim to be disillusioned government workers, their tweets betraying a deep sense of betrayal. A fleeting moment of official rebellion occurred when the Badlands National Park account bravely tweeted about global warming, only for the posts to be swiftly and shamefully deleted. This act of suppression, the people behind @AltNatParkSer revealed, was the catalyst for their own defiant emergence, prompting other alternative accounts and even some official US national park accounts to tweet about climate change on Wednesday. By Nathan Williams, BBC UGC & Social news team

British Marine's latest report unveils a robust landscape for the leisure, superyacht, and small commercial marine industry, with superyacht revenues alone soaring to £605 million for the year concluding April 2016. The broader sector's revenue ascended 1.6% to £3.01 billion, marking the first time since 2008-2009 that the £3 billion threshold has been surpassed. However, this momentum is projected to decelerate in 2017, as the looming uncertainty of Brexit negotiations is anticipated to temper demand. Following the financial crisis, total revenue had plummeted, hitting a nadir of £2.85 billion in the 2011-2012 financial year, before steadily regaining ground, a resurgence largely propelled by increased revenue from engine and equipment manufacturing alongside a notable surge in sales of hire and charter boats. While exports for the year saw a marginal dip of 0.7% to £882 million, British Marine noted a recent boon: the post-referendum depreciation of the pound against the dollar and euro has invigorated overseas buying power. Yet, businesses surveyed for the report temper this optimism, viewing the boost from the weakened currency as a fleeting advantage. Howard Pridding, chief executive of British Marine, affirmed the sector's resilience, stating: "The industry remains robust - revenue is growing and we are taking on more employees. Despite the post-referendum volatility impacting on business and consumer confidence, the industry remains bullish." The report reiterates the expectation of a growth slowdown in 2017, attributing it to escalating economic volatility as negotiations for the UK's departure from the European Union draw nearer and unfold. Sunseeker and Princess stand as the UK's preeminent superyacht manufacturers, and globally, the British marine industry commands the fourth-largest turnover.

Russia unveiled a deal on Thursday to establish four "de-escalation zones" in Syria, backed by Turkey and Iran. The main Syrian opposition grouping, the High Negotiations Committee (HNC), expressed skepticism on Friday, stating the plan lacked "safeguards and compliance mechanisms" and rejecting Iran as a guarantor. In contrast, UN special envoy Staffan de Mistura told the BBC the agreement was significant due to its implementation by the three key countries. While not a signatory, the Syrian government has expressed support for the plan via its state news agency. The United States voiced concern regarding Iran's role, asserting the country had "only contributed to the violence, not stopped it."

The "memorandum on the creation of de-escalation areas," announced by the Russian military after talks in Astana, Kazakhstan, aims to halt attacks by all sides, "provide the conditions for the safe and voluntary return of refugees," and facilitate the speedy provision of relief supplies and medical aid. Russia's foreign ministry published the full text of the agreement on Saturday. The four zones are intended to remain in place for six months, with their borders to be finalized by Russia, Iran, and Turkey by June 4. Russian Deputy Defence Minister Alexander Fomin stated on Friday that Russian aviation had ceased bombing raids in these four zones since May 1, though he stressed that operations against Islamic State (IS) militants elsewhere in Syria would continue.

Despite the agreement, violence persists. Activists reported government aircraft hitting central Hama province, and shelling and gunfire were noted elsewhere. The UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights (SOHR) confirmed Syrian fighter jets bombed rebel positions in Hama on Saturday, a report corroborated by a rebel commander to Reuters. The Syrian military has not yet commented.

These Astana talks sought to reinforce a frequently violated ceasefire initially agreed upon in December. A partial cessation of hostilities was declared late last year, but fighting has continued across multiple fronts in Syria's war, which has claimed over 300,000 lives since 2011.

After fourteen hours of impassioned debate, Argentina's Senate, by a narrow margin of just six votes, passed the landmark same-sex marriage legislation, a measure already approved by the Chamber of Deputies. This pivotal law, which also extends adoption rights to same-sex couples, had faced fierce opposition from the Catholic Church and other religious groups, yet found strong advocacy from President Cristina Fernandez's centre-left government. The final vote stood at 33 to 27, with three abstentions. As the debate unfolded into the early hours of Thursday, rival demonstrations animated the streets outside Congress, where supporters and opponents voiced their convictions. Maria Rachid, president of the Argentine Federation of Lesbians, Gays, Bisexuals and Transsexuals, noted that "nearly every political and social figure has spoken out in favour of marriage equality," expressing hope that "Argentina, from today forward, is a more just country for all families." Conversely, Ines Frank of Argentine Families Argentina asserted that opposition was not discrimination, but rather a belief that "the essence of a family is between two people of opposite sexes." This legislation resolves a period of legal controversy, marked by several recent gay marriages that had been annulled by the Supreme Court. While civil unions for same-sex couples were legal in Buenos Aires and some provinces, a comprehensive nationwide law had been absent. Argentina's capital, widely celebrated as one of Latin America's most gay-friendly cities, was notably the first in the region to legalize same-sex unions, placing the nation at the forefront of a broader regional shift, as civil unions are also recognized in Uruguay and parts of Brazil and Mexico, with gay marriage legal in Mexico City.

The political landscape is in a frenzy as the nation barrels towards a snap election on June 8th, a seismic announcement from Prime Minister Theresa May that MPs overwhelmingly endorsed. While the SNP's 54 sitting MPs anticipate swift endorsement, the true test lies in the precarious fate of Natalie McGarry and Michelle Thomson, former SNP MPs now navigating the scene as independents. Intriguingly, it was only these two who defied the consensus, voting against the election, in stark contrast to the SNP's collective abstention. Should they not return, the SNP faces the challenge of finding five new candidates, including three for seats that eluded them in 2015 – a telling indicator of their ambitions. Already, the scramble for the SNP ticket has begun in Glasgow East and Edinburgh West, the very seats once held by the two women. The urgency is palpable across the board: UK Labour issued a frantic call for candidates via Twitter on Friday, demanding applications by Sunday noon, a tight window reflecting the election's suddenness. Scottish Labour's executive meets this weekend to finalize their selection, with leader Kezia Dugdale projecting an air of preparedness, asserting they were "ready." Their sole Scottish MP, Ian Murray, swiftly launched his campaign to defend Edinburgh South, a crucial battle for Labour's presence north of the border, with Scottish Secretary David Mundell predictably following suit. Across the spectrum, candidacies are rapidly being declared, signaling the intensity of the impending contest. Notably, Tory MSP Douglas Ross, a Holyrood newcomer, has bravely declared he will challenge the formidable SNP depute leader Angus Robertson in Moray—a true David vs. Goliath battle in the making. Adding to the drama, former Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson is seeking a compelling rematch with John Nicolson in East Dunbartonshire, two years after he dramatically unseated her. The Lib Dems, meanwhile, are making a bold statement with all-female shortlists in several target seats, including Edinburgh West, with decisions potentially finalized this very weekend, highlighting their strategic approach to this pivotal election.

Ahead of UN talks in Geneva, Oxfam called for the resettlement of 10% of the 4.8 million Syrians displaced by the civil war by the end of 2016, highlighting that only 1.4% had received assistance so far. The charity deemed the UK's plan to resettle 20,000 Syrians by 2020 insufficient. While acknowledging the UK's substantial financial contribution—£2.3 billion, making it the second-largest bilateral donor globally after the US—Oxfam argued that Britain "can and should do more." The organization contended that economically robust, developed nations ought to bear a greater share of responsibility for refugees than countries like Lebanon and Jordan, which already host thousands of Syrians. Oxfam further advocated for the Geneva conference to yield "urgent solutions, offering people safe and legal routes to a welcome" in other countries. An Oxfam analysis of 28 OECD member nations and signatories to the 1951 Convention on Refugees revealed pledges for nearly 130,000 Syrian refugees, yet only 67,000 have actually been resettled. This 10% target represents the most vulnerable refugees identified by the UN as requiring resettlement. Oxfam's assessment, based on economic capacity, indicated that only Canada, Germany, and Norway had exceeded their "fair share" of resettlement pledges. Five other nations—Australia, Finland, Iceland, Sweden, and New Zealand—had pledged over half of their fair share, while the UK committed to 22%, the US to 7%, and France to merely 4%. Mark Goldring, Chief Executive of Oxfam GB, expressed dismay, stating, "It's shocking that while people continue to flee Syria most countries have failed to provide a safe home for the most vulnerable."

The final print edition of Newsweek will be published on December 31, a move reflecting the broader industry trend of newspapers and magazines transitioning to digital-only platforms amid declining traditional advertising revenue. Newsweek, which commenced publication in 1933 and rose to become the second-largest U.S. news weekly, has seen its subscriber base decline significantly from over 3 million to 1.5 million. This, coupled with diminishing print advertising revenues, led to its sale by the Washington Post Company in 2010 and subsequent merger with the digital news group The Daily Beast. Tina Brown, founder of The Daily Beast, reported that its digital platform now attracts over 15 million unique monthly visitors, a 70% increase from the previous year. While acknowledging the inherent difficulty of discontinuing print for those who cherish its "romance" and "weekly camaraderie," Brown emphasized the necessity to "embrace the all-digital future" to sustain its journalism. The new digital-only "Newsweek Global" will be available via subscription, aiming to capitalize on the burgeoning market of over 70 million tablet users in the U.S., a figure that has dramatically increased in recent years. However, industry analysts caution that standing out in the increasingly competitive digital landscape will present a significant challenge. Brown clarified that this decision was driven by "the challenging economics of print publishing and distribution," rather than any compromise on the brand's quality or journalistic integrity.

Spencer Flower, a 72-year-old Conservative councillor, has been found culpable of illegally casting a vote in 2013, a decision from which a social housing firm he was associated with stood to benefit. Despite his conviction, he retains his public office, though his political future remains uncertain.

A district judge at Bournemouth Magistrates' Court ruled that Flower's participation in a critical 2013 debate regarding East Dorset's housing strategy contravened the Localism Act 2011. While serving as a non-executive director for Synergy Housing Ltd – a charitable social housing company from which he received an annual allowance of approximately £5,000 – Flower voted on a proposal to refer the strategy to the secretary of state for approval. His declaration of interest prior to the meeting did not, however, absolve him of culpability for voting "without reasonable excuse," given his direct pecuniary interest. The core strategy, which included redevelopment plans for Wimborne, held potential for Synergy's properties to be improved by developers like Wyatt.

Flower, who had stepped aside as leader of Dorset County Council following his charges in November, was handed a six-month conditional discharge—the lowest possible penalty—and ordered to pay £930 in costs. Emerging from court, he expressed surprise and disappointment, attributing the conviction to a "technicality" and emphasizing the court's acknowledgement of his "total lack of any personal gain or intent."

Though two prior charges related to undisclosed interests in Zebra Property Solutions Ltd were dropped, Flower's continued membership on East Dorset District Council has been confirmed. However, with nominations for the forthcoming local elections still open, his intent to seek re-election remains unstated, casting a shadow over his long public career.

On Sunday, Mr. Joshua proclaimed to his congregation that he "saw" a woman winning the US presidency. Yet, following Donald Trump's convincing victory on Tuesday, visitors to the wealthy pastor's Facebook page noticed the prophecy had been quietly removed. Known to his many followers as "the prophet," this influential evangelist is one of Nigeria's most recognized and popular figures across Africa, with numerous top politicians among his flock.

The US election prediction, initially broadcast on Mr. Joshua's Emmanuel TV channel and subsequently uploaded to YouTube, featured prominently. A section of this "prophecy"—declaring, "Ten days ago I saw the president of America with a narrow win... What I frankly saw was a woman"—was also posted on his Facebook page before its disappearance.

The internet, however, remembers. TB Joshua quickly became a trending topic on Twitter across Nigeria, Ghana, and South Africa, as people gleefully shared memes poking fun at his unfulfilled prediction. A deluge of complaints also swamped a Facebook entry he posted on Wednesday. "Why was the prophecy deleted? If this was uttered by the man of God, why remove it?" questioned South Africa's Clive Mashiri.

Despite the backlash, some remained steadfast. "I will always believe in your prophesies, through thick and thin," affirmed South African Gugu Mathonsi, reflecting the enduring faith many hold in TB Joshua's purported supernatural powers, which include healing and prophecy. Indeed, his influence has long been acknowledged by political leaders: Ghana's late President John Atta Mills publicly stated in 2008 that he had consulted the preacher throughout his successful election campaign, while Tanzanian President John Magufuli and Malawi's former leader Joyce Banda have also paid homage to him in the past.

At the annual World's Biggest Liar competition, entrants have five minutes to spin the most convincing lie they can. This year's champion, George Kemp of Maryport, Cumbria, won despite "struggling" with a chest infection. His winning tale involved building a small submarine out of his dad's old bubble car, which he sailed to the Isle of Man. There, he declared, he "ended up bumping into Donald Trump and his wife in an underwater hotel." The fantastical journey continued as he encountered more famous faces aboard a Scottish submarine made of shortbread tins – a vessel he claimed Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond had sold to the United States. Last year's winner, Mike Naylor, known as "Monkey Liar," from Wasdale, secured second place this year, with Helen Jordan taking third. The contest, which dates back to the 19th century, is steeped in tradition, having seen previous champions like comedian Sue Perkins in 2006. In 2014, its renown even drew an entrant from Germany. Held at the Bridge Inn at Santon Bridge before a panel of judges and an audience, the rules famously bar politicians and legal professionals, humorously deeming them "too well versed to apply." The event honours Will Ritson, a legendary Wasdale landlord and famous fibber. Ritson once claimed the local turnips were so immense, people had to "quarry" into them for Sunday lunch, and the hollowed-out shells then served as sheds for the Herdwick sheep from the fells.

Mark Footitt's 3-52 spearheaded a challenging period for the visiting team, who lost five wickets before lunch, including opener Alex Davies, stand-in captain Liam Livingstone, and Dane Vilas. Sam Curran contributed with the dismissal of England opener Haseeb Hameed for a second-ball duck, while Tom Curran also secured a wicket, leaving Lancashire in a precarious position with five wickets down within 22 overs. However, the innings was resiliently rebuilt by an unbeaten partnership between Jordan Clark, who scored 108 not out from 133 balls, and Shivnarine Chanderpaul, with 85 not out. Chanderpaul initially provided stability, adding 55 runs with Ryan McLaren before Clark joined him following McLaren's dismissal by Gareth Batty. The pair then forged an unbroken 172-run stand, with Clark, batting at number eight, reaching his century with a six shortly before the close and outpacing Chanderpaul to his half-century during their collaboration. Despite the evening session being halted due to bad light, Clark's performance remained unhindered; the 26-year-old, whose previous highest score was 84 not out, concluded the day having struck 17 fours and three sixes. This remarkable turnaround for Lancashire was particularly noteworthy given their vulnerable position early in the match.

In March 1981, just weeks into Ronald Reagan's presidency, a shooting outside a Washington hotel injured the president and three others, sending shockwaves across the world. The assailant, John Hinckley, had acted in an apparent bid to impress actress Jodie Foster, with whom he harbored an obsession now termed stalking. While President Reagan, shot in the lung, ultimately recovered, his press secretary James Brady sustained a severe head wound, leading to brain damage and lifelong reliance on a wheelchair; Brady's death in 2014 at 73 was later ruled a homicide, though no additional charges were filed against Hinckley. Two law enforcement officers also suffered less serious injuries in the attack. Found not guilty by reason of insanity, Hinckley was committed for treatment to a Washington hospital. Decades later, in July, U.S. District Judge Paul Friedman ruled that the now 61-year-old Hinckley no longer posed a danger to himself or the public, citing medical assessments that showed "no symptoms of active mental illness" since 1983. Under strict conditions, Hinckley had already been spending 17 days a month at his mother's Virginia home, and his full release and arrival there on a recent Saturday were reported by the Associated Press. The comprehensive court order and opinion, detailing Hinckley's psychiatric history and treatment alongside the terms of his release, are publicly available on the website of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

This critical local hub, once a lifeline, was severed, forcing animals, particularly injured ones, on arduous journeys to distant facilities like Cross Hands in Carmarthenshire – a trek that bled farmers further financially. Andrew Bayne, 37, and his 22-year-old nephew Michael Bagnall, both from Lewisham, have now been convicted of his murder and await sentencing at the Old Bailey on November 20.

The court heard how the tragic chain of events began last November. Mr. Purdy, accompanied by friends Callum Malone and Jack Walker, initially faced Bagnall in what was described as a "skirmish." However, this brief confrontation ignited a vengeful pursuit, with Bayne and Bagnall embarking on a hunt through Bermondsey for Mr. Purdy. Their relentless search culminated in Mossington Gardens, where Andrew Bayne unleashed a fatal shot to Mr. Purdy's head, before menacingly turning the weapon towards Callum and fleeing the scene. Mr. Purdy suffered "catastrophic injuries," his young life extinguished the very next day.

Prosecutors revealed the chilling, petty motive: despite having a new girlfriend, Michael Bagnall's resentment over his ex-partner moving on festered, leading him to inundate her with threatening messages via phone and Facebook. Driven to his breaking point, Ben, joined by Callum and Jack, decided that Sunday lunchtime to confront Bagnall and "have it out." Prosecutor Crispin Aylett QC described this desperate act as "undoubtedly a very stupid thing to have sought to do," a decision that tragically cost Ben Purdy his life. The competition, run by TV channel Dave, has previously been won by comedians such as Tim Vine, Stewart Francis, and Zoe Lyon. Graham, from West Bromwich, secured this year's victory after being shortlisted in both 2014 and 2015. He remarked, "It's an incredible honour to land Joke of the Fringe. Judges evaluated an average of 60 different comedy performances, sifting through over 3,600 minutes of material before making their selections. Abba trois."

Get ready for some exciting news! The renowned Halle Orchestra plans to open a brand-new primary and secondary school right in Stoke-on-Trent, with an ambitious launch set for 2020. Teaming up with an academy trust, their vision is clear and powerful: as John Summers, the orchestra's chief executive, puts it, they’ll use music to "raise aspirations" across *all* academic subjects. This incredible proposal, developed with the City Learning Trust, is part of the free schools programme, and we’re eagerly awaiting approval from the Department for Education.

But the Halle is already determined to open its doors by September 2020, welcoming students from seven to 19 years old. Imagine this: young musicians enjoying masterclasses from top professionals, regular access to concerts, and incredible artists in residence. Students will dedicate a significant 40% of their time to specialist music classes, collaborating directly with the Halle Choir, the Halle Youth Orchestra, and Halle for Youth.

As John Summers emphasizes, "The Halle has a huge amount of expertise and experience in working at high level performance, both in terms of instrumental coaching and choral training." And crucially, he adds, our expertise will also "help develop music in the curriculum as a means of supporting academic achievement and aspiration."

And this isn't just a dream – it’s a proven model! Look at Bremen in Germany, where a leading orchestra courageously set up its rehearsal rooms and headquarters within a comprehensive school on a housing estate. The musicians of the Deutsche Kammerphilharmonie Bremen didn't just visit; they became part of the school's daily fabric. The result? Truancy

Belgian broadcasters observed a march defined by its profound calm and echoing silence. Originally planned for a week after the March 22nd attacks, the demonstration had been reluctantly postponed by officials due to lingering security threats, a stark reminder of the city's vulnerability. On Sunday, a diverse tapestry of humanity converged: grieving relatives, the stoic paramedics and airport staff forever marked by the tragedy, and people of various faiths, all united in shared grief and defiance. Each hand held flowers, a vibrant, fragrant tribute to those whose lives were so cruelly extinguished. Their path wound through the Molenbeek neighbourhood – a place shadowed by the alleged presence of the Brussels and Paris attackers – before culminating at the poignant, makeshift memorial outside the city's stock exchange, a raw wound in the urban fabric. Yet, the turnout, a mere fraction of the 15,000 organisers had fervently hoped for, subtly underscored the lingering climate of fear.
