Cairn announced it had received clearance from Senegalese government officials to commence an evaluation plan for its offshore assets. The company, which made two discoveries in the area last year and estimated the fields could contain over a billion barrels of oil, will initiate its evaluation plan shortly with a 3D seismic survey. A multi-well exploration and appraisal programme is subsequently scheduled to begin later this year. Cairn, headquartered in Edinburgh, holds a 40% interest in three offshore Senegalese blocks: Sangomar Deep, Sangomar Offshore, and Rufisque Offshore. Its partners include ConocoPhillips (35%) and FAR Ltd (15%), with Petrosen, the Senegal National Oil Company, retaining a 10% interest during the exploration phase.

Concurrently, Cairn's latest half-yearly report revealed the initiation of international arbitration proceedings against the government of India concerning a tax dispute. Indian authorities have prevented Cairn from realizing the value of its 10% residual shareholding in Cairn India Limited (CIL). In March, the company was issued a tax assessment totaling $1.6 billion, including interest and penalties, pertaining to the 2006-07 tax year, during which it was preparing for the initial public offering of Cairn India on the Mumbai stock exchange. Cairn has contested this assessment and intends to seek restitution for losses incurred due to the declining value of its CIL stake. The stake's value decreased from $1 billion in December 2013 to $526 million as of June 30 this year, primarily attributable to lower oil prices. This reduced valuation led Cairn to record a $177.1 million impairment loss in its first half, contributing to a reported post-tax loss of $230 million, an increase from $62 million in the prior year. Security forces employed tear gas and live ammunition to disperse predominantly Shia Muslim crowds protesting corruption and security deficiencies, leading to reports of at least 50 demonstrators sustaining injuries. A curfew imposed by officials in the Iraqi capital has since been rescinded. This incident marked the second occasion within the month that demonstrators had breached the city's heavily fortified Green Zone, which encompasses the parliament, vital government structures, and numerous foreign embassies. Some demonstrators succeeded in entering the Prime Minister's office and the Parliament building before authorities subsequently announced that full control of the area had been re-established and protesters had withdrawn. Protesters accuse the government of neglecting essential reforms amidst its ongoing campaign against the Islamic State group (IS) and declining oil revenues. IS, a Sunni jihadist group, controls portions of western and northern Iraq and has been responsible for a series of recent attacks resulting in dozens of fatalities. Shia Muslim cleric Moqtada Sadr condemned the use of force, expressing support for the demonstrators' "peaceful and spontaneous revolt." Sadr and his militia, the Mehdi Army, rose to prominence following the 2003 US-led invasion of Iraq, galvanizing anti-US sentiment and engaging in repeated clashes with US forces, whose withdrawal the cleric consistently advocated. An arrest warrant was issued for Sadr in 2004 in connection with the murder of a rival cleric, and his militia was implicated in the torture and killing of thousands of Sunnis during the sectarian violence of 2006-2007, a period during which Sadr sought refuge in Iran. In 2011, Sadr returned from self-imposed exile to Iraq, adopting a more conciliatory tone and advocating for national unity and peace. Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi, who assumed office in 2014, has pledged to eradicate corruption and alleviate sectarian tensions. He has advocated for radical reforms and seeks to establish a government of technocrats, but this initiative has faced opposition from lawmakers, as reported by Jim Muir of the BBC in Baghdad. The parliament remains deeply divided, preventing the formation of a quorum required for official sessions. Iraq's system of allocating government positions has consistently drawn criticism for promoting unqualified individuals and fostering corruption; while the government maintains a delicate balance between party and religious loyalties, the nation ranks 161st out of 168 countries on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, underscoring systemic corruption.

Muslim cleric Mehboob Akhtar of Stoke-on-Trent was sentenced to 14 years in prison at Birmingham Crown Court, alongside nine others, including his wife and daughter. They were found guilty of lying to mortgage lenders to amass nearly £1 million in property, aiming to "control and dominate" areas of the city. Following a trial last month, the 60-year-old, from Farman Close in Fenton, was convicted of 11 charges, including five counts of conspiracy to commit fraud and cheating Her Majesty's Revenue and Customs (HMRC) out of £271,000. The court heard how Akhtar, also known as Saint Pirwali Pandariman, masterminded the conspiracy over more than a decade, between 2003 and 2014. Originally from Pakistan, he was a prominent faith leader in Fenton, reportedly raising millions in donations for poverty relief through the area's Darbar Unique Centre. However, Judge Stephen Eyre stated that Akhtar had "let down his followers," remarking, "You used the prestige and devotion of others to facilitate this offending. Your role as a spiritual guide provided cover and you financed your activities through donations obtained in part because of your spiritual role." The court revealed that Akhtar largely kept his name off the paperwork, using his wife, daughter, and niece to apply for mortgages. When police searched homes and offices linked to the group in September 2012, they discovered forged documents and emails related to the conspiracy. His wife, Khadija Akhtar, 54, of Hartwell Lane, Stoke, was convicted of offences including cheating HMRC and conspiracy to obtain a money transfer by deception, receiving a sentence of four years and three months. Their daughter, Rushbamani Akhtar, 29, was sentenced to three-and-a-half years after being convicted of entering into an arrangement to facilitate the acquisition, retention, use or control of criminal property and conspiracy to commit fraud. Seven others, including two mortgage brokers, were also sentenced for charges such as conspiracy to defraud and obtaining money transfers by deception. After the sentencing, Chief Superintendent Martin Evans of Staffordshire Police described the sentences as the culmination of a "very long and complex investigation."

Four years have spun since the golden light first crowned her brow, and now, at Rio 2016, Jade Jones, the reigning champion of the -57kg category, stands poised to defend her hard-won reign. From the valleys of north Wales, a young Jade, barely a whisper of her future might, found her spark in the televised triumphs of legends like Kelly Holmes. That early flicker ignited a dream for gold, a dream she now embodies. "To think I'm one of those role models now," she reflects, "and people are looking up to me is lovely." Her own journey, a testament to televised dreams, has since fanned a widespread flame, with countless girls drawn to taekwondo in the wake of her London glory.

Remus Hamza, 40, stands accused of raping a 20-year-old woman on September 20 near Cardiff University as she walked home alone after a night out. Hamza, a Romanian national residing in Cardiff, denies the charge. The prosecution at Newport Crown Court alleges the victim was so severely intoxicated that she was incapable of consenting to sex.

The court heard that the woman became separated from her friends and began walking home around 02:00 GMT, following a route along Greyfriars Road, through an underpass by City Hall, and then along Museum Avenue. It was there that Hamza allegedly approached her, and the assault occurred behind a bush.

Prosecutor Claire Pickthall told the jury that the victim's "extreme drunkenness" rendered her unable to recall the incident or even having sex. Pickthall asserted that this level of intoxication precluded any state of consent, declaring, "The actions in these circumstances amount to rape." She further characterized Hamza as "preying on single, drunk females."

A key witness, Lee Neill, testified that he observed Mr. Hamza walking with the victim behind the National Museum of Wales and, suspecting something "sinister," followed them. Mr. Neill took a photograph "to use as evidence," the flash of which startled Hamza, causing him to flee. After a brief chase, Mr. Neill lost Hamza and returned to the victim, subsequently calling the police.

However, the court heard that due to her profound confusion, the victim initially identified Mr. Neill as her attacker. He was arrested and questioned before being released. DNA evidence later led police to arrest Mr. Hamza.

The victim herself testified, recalling consuming wine, cider, and cocktails during her night out. While she had limited memory of her journey home or the attack, she adamantly stated she would never have consented to sex with a stranger, adding, "I have a moral compass."

Helen Bailey, 51, was found dead in a cesspit at her Royston, Hertfordshire home in July 2016, having been missing since April 11. Her fiancé, Ian Stewart, denies murder.

The trial heard from Edward Farmer, who initially told St Albans Crown Court he saw Ms Bailey alone in a dark 4x4, resembling a Range Rover, on Charlotte Street in Broadstairs – near her holiday home – sometime between mid-April and June. This testimony directly contradicted defence claims that Ms Bailey had been kidnapped by two violent men and taken to Broadstairs.

However, under cross-examination by the prosecution, Mr Farmer's account unraveled. He admitted the alleged sighting could have occurred in March – weeks before Ms Bailey was reported missing by Mr Stewart on April 15. Furthermore, he conceded he had "no reason at all" to recall the sighting until interviewed by a reporter from The Sun in June.

Mr Stewart, 56, of Baldock Road, Royston, faces charges of drugging and suffocating his wife-to-be before disposing of her body in the cesspit beneath their garage. He denies murder, preventing a lawful burial, fraud, and three counts of perverting the course of justice. The trial continues.

At a campaign rally in New Hampshire, a supporter addressing Republican candidate Donald Trump stated, "We have a problem in this country - it's called Muslims," and falsely claimed President Obama is a Muslim and not an American. The man continued, alleging, "We have training camps growing where they want to kill us. That's my question: When can we get rid of them?" Mr. Trump, who had initially said, "I like this guy," and laughed, responded that "bad things are happening" and he would "look into them," without clarifying that President Obama is a Christian American.

Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton criticized Mr. Trump's "failure to denounce 'hateful rhetoric'," tweeting that his "not denouncing false statements about POTUS & hateful rhetoric about Muslims is disturbing & just plain wrong." Democratic National Committee chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz added in a statement that Mr. Trump's "racism knows no bounds."

Mr. Trump's campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, sought to minimize the incident, stating to US media that he "all he heard was a question about training camps." Lewandowski further asserted, "The media wants to make this issue about Obama. The bigger issue is that Obama is waging a war against Christians in this country."

This event drew comparisons to a 2008 campaign moment when Republican nominee John McCain intervened after a woman expressed distrust of Mr. Obama, calling him "an Arab." President Obama, who openly identifies as Christian, was born in Hawaii to an American mother and a Kenyan father. However, Mr. Trump was a prominent figure in 2011 challenging Mr. Obama to produce his birth certificate, which the president subsequently did, to counter rumors of a Kenyan birth. Despite having no political experience, Mr. Trump currently leads his Republican rivals in polls more than a year before polling day.

His conviction on the Calais migrant crisis is clear: "These are human beings, these are people in desperate situations – they need our help and they need our support." He told me he believes the UK must do more, advocating for participation in European programs for refugees and noting the grassroots efforts of those taking aid to Calais. The Institute for Economics and Peace (IEP) reports that the total costs of conflict globally amounted to 13.4% of world GDP, a sum equivalent to the combined economies of Brazil, Canada, France, Germany, Spain, and the United Kingdom. The annual report highlights a deepening disparity between the most and least peaceful nations, with Iceland ranked as the world's most peaceful and Syria as the least. Libya experienced the most severe deterioration in 2014, while the Middle East and North Africa now stands as the world's most violent region, surpassing South Asia's 2013 ranking.

The human toll of conflict is significant, with 180,000 lives lost in 2014, a stark increase from 49,000 in 2010. Deaths attributable to terrorism surged by 61% in 2013, resulting in nearly 18,000 fatalities, predominantly in Iraq, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Nigeria, and Syria. The IEP further notes that substantial cost increases are driven by deaths from internal conflict, support for internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees, UN peacekeeping operations, and GDP losses. Specifically, the cost of supporting approximately 50 million refugees and IDPs – the highest number since World War II – escalated by 267% since 2008, reaching $128 billion.

IEP Chief Executive Steve Killelea identified the "inequality in peace" worldwide as the most surprising finding. While some Western European countries have achieved "historic levels of peace," characterized by exceptionally low murder rates and security spending, nations such as Iraq, Syria, Nigeria, South Sudan, and the Central African Republic have become significantly more violent. The report concludes that a mere 10% reduction in global violence would inject an additional $1.43 trillion into the world economy. This amount surpasses six times the sum required to eliminate Greece's debts and is three times greater than the total earnings of the world's 1.1 billion poorest individuals.

The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has fined Falcon and Pointer £175,000 for making automated calls regarding PPI, and Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd £50,000 for calls asking to speak to deceased relatives. Both companies claimed these calls were made by a third party.

Anne Jones, Assistant Commissioner for Wales, stated that the enforcement action underscores the ICO's commitment to addressing non-compliant cold-calling practices. She noted that investigations increasingly point to Swansea as a significant hub for such activities in the UK, where companies employ practices described as illicit, resulting in calls that are often bothersome and at times distressing. The ICO has taken action against six companies since 2013.

Further details revealed that Falcon and Pointer's license was revoked in January 2016. Despite informing the ICO it had ceased calls in June 2015, an investigation found the company made an additional two million calls in the subsequent two months. Direct Choice Home Improvements Ltd, which sells windows, doors, and conservatories, received 168 complaints over a six-month period.

Ms. Jones reiterated that the ICO's actions aim to ensure cold-callers in Swansea adhere to regulations. She emphasized that both companies had been previously contacted but continued to make nuisance calls, leading to frustration and harassment for many individuals.

Sandra Busby, managing director of the Welsh Contact Centre Forum, distinguished between legitimate market practices, such as credible companies contacting existing customers, and "disreputable, unethical companies" that "flagrantly disregard rules" for "a quick buck," which she stated harms the industry's reputation. She affirmed the Forum's focus on helping companies achieve best practice.

This latest enforcement coincided with the ICO's publication of its updated Direct Marketing Guidance, designed to assist organizations in understanding and complying with relevant laws and good practice.

It's an absolute outrage, an unconscionable betrayal, that two dedicated nurses, Kevin Gregson and Peter Hilton, have been ruthlessly sacked from Ashworth. Their 'crime'? Simply defending themselves and their colleagues during a terrifying, violent struggle with a patient who headbutted and spat at staff. The Prison Officers' Association (POA) rightly asserts that these brave men used nothing more than 'reasonable force,' yet Mersey Care Trust, the very body supposedly running this high-security hospital, claims their dismissal was the 'only option.' This is a blatant disregard for the safety and well-being of the very people who put their lives on the line daily. The public, I believe, will be rightly appalled and deeply sympathetic to Mr. Hilton and Mr. Gregson, who were merely reacting to a horrific act of aggression. While the patient, thankfully, came to no harm, the nurses certainly did – a detail the Trust seems to conveniently overlook. Their hollow statements about 'duty of care' ring utterly false when they so callously abandon their own staff. This strike, which began at 07:00 GMT, is not just understandable; it's a necessary stand against such an egregious injustice. The Trust's 'disappointment' at the union's decision before an independent tribunal is simply baffling; what else could they expect when their actions are so clearly indefensible? Their lauded, 'award-winning' reputation for caring for 'complex and vulnerable adults' feels like a cruel joke when their own carers are treated with such contempt. To suggest they 'never dismiss staff lightly' is an insult to common sense when the 'evidence' leads to such a shocking conclusion – a conclusion that utterly fails to protect those who protect others.

Charles Blackman's "Women Lovers" unveils a tender, intimate tableau: two nude forms, gracefully entwined in repose, a feline shadow keeping silent vigil on a quiet bed. Yet, when art broker Mossgreen sought to share this gentle beauty on Facebook, the digital gatekeepers recoiled, branding the masterpiece "advertising adult products or services"—a stark rejection of its inherent grace. Paul Summer, Mossgreen's chief executive, decried the decision as "ridiculous," lamenting, "This is a very beautiful image that is not overtly sexual in any shape or form. It's like going back to the 1950s. It's ridiculous to censor this sort of thing." Facebook's cold decree remained unyielding, citing "negative user sentiment" and a "zero tolerance" policy, echoing the censorship battles over even a Gustave Courbet nude. This very painting, poised to command over A$45,000 at auction, found itself snared in the algorithm's unseeing gaze. Summer mused on the absurdity: "Nobody said a single thing until Facebook suddenly decided it was going to offend somebody. I don't know who they're protecting because I have two teenage daughters myself and if I said to them that this painting has been banned I think they would have laughed at me." At 88, Blackman stands as "the last man standing" from a luminous era of Australian art, a peer to giants like Arthur Boyd and Sidney Nolan, his works, such as "The Game of Chess" which once fetched A$1.78m, revered as treasures. As Summer affirmed, "Charles Blackman is the most well-regarded and respected living Australian artist," yet even such a master's vision risks being dimmed by the ever-watchful, often uncomprehending, eye of the digital age.

John le Carré's classic Cold War novel, *The Spy Who Came In From The Cold*, originally published in 1963 and adapted into a 1965 film starring Richard Burton, is slated for a new television series adaptation. Set in 1962, shortly after the construction of the Berlin Wall, the narrative chronicles the experiences of Alec Leamas, a British intelligence officer whose East Berlin network is decimated by the actions of East German counter-intelligence officer Hans-Dieter Mundt. Recalled to London, Leamas is presented with an opportunity for retribution. Oscar-winning writer Simon Beaufoy, known for *Slumdog Millionaire*, is penning the adaptation, which will be a co-production between BBC One and US network AMC. This collaboration follows their critically acclaimed work on *The Night Manager*, which earned Golden Globes for Tom Hiddleston, Hugh Laurie, and Olivia Colman, and a nomination for Best Mini-Series or TV Film. John le Carré himself expressed considerable excitement and confidence in the project, a sentiment echoed by Beaufoy, who lauded it as "the best Cold War spy story ever written." Piers Wenger, Controller of BBC Drama, further underscored the significance of le Carré's return to BBC One, stating it was a "privilege to announce that John le Carre will return... with one of the best spy thrillers ever written" following the global success of *The Night Manager*. The series will be produced by The Ink Factory, the company behind *The Night Manager*, in association with Character 7.

A fascinating glimpse into the evolving minds of young storytellers emerges from the Oxford University Press's monumental analysis of over 120,000 short stories submitted to the BBC's 500 Words competition. It's striking how technology now anchors their daily existence, yet their literary reflections on it are in constant, swift flux. Once-ubiquitous terms like 'email,' 'mobile,' and 'Facebook' are fading, eclipsed by the likes of 'Instagram,' 'Snapchat,' and the omnipresent 'emoji.' Even 'television' has yielded its crown to the 'phone.' Perhaps most tellingly, the humble hashtag now punctuates their narratives, morphing from a simple search term into a powerful editorial device. Children are deftly employing it to inject drama or comment, almost as if saying, '#IblameTwitter #AndInstagram' directly from the page. As Vineeta Gupta of Oxford University Press observed, this represents a "significant change," with children extending the hashtag's use "from a simple prefix or as a search term for Twitter to an editorial device to add drama or comment." The technological graveyard also claims 'iPod,' 'MP3,' and 'Blackberry,' replaced by the ascendancy of 'iPhone,' 'WhatsApp,' and 'ooVoo' — a clear command to '#keepup' with their digital dexterity.

Intriguingly, a dominant narrative arc now centers on the quest for sudden internet fame via YouTube videos. Their tales no longer merely recount *watching* videos; instead, they obsessively track the hits, shares, and likes their own creations garner—a compelling shift that '#makesabetterstory' in their digital world. Their character rosters are a fascinating, eclectic mix: classic figures like Cinderella and Snow White jostle for space with modern icons Lionel Messi and Wayne Rooney, and, shockingly, Adolf Hitler. Yet, researchers were genuinely surprised by the surge of mythological characters—Zeus, the Minotaur, and Hercules—proving, perhaps, '#theyloveZeus' after all. While World War One remains a perennial backdrop, and current events in Ukraine and Syria frequently appear, all pale in comparison to the overwhelming narrative dominance of Ebola, with the relentless search for a cure forming countless central plots. Their linguistic inventiveness also blossoms, birthing whimsical neologisms like 'wellysaurus,' the evocative 'gloomful,' and 'Stegasuarez'—a truly monstrous hybrid of Stegosaurus and footballer Luis Suarez, prompting the thought, '#itbites'! The transfer window cast a complex shadow over Cardiff City, with manager Russell Slade navigating a labyrinth of speculation, ambition, and pointed denials. At the heart of the swirling rumours was 23-year-old Heracles forward Wout Weghorst, who, according to his own declaration, was poised to finalize a move to the Championship club. However, Slade emphatically dismissed these reports, acknowledging only a fleeting "initial inquiry some time ago," before firmly stating: "To my knowledge that's not something we're going to pursue." This stance directly contradicted Heracles chairman Jam Smit, who believed a fee had been agreed for the Netherlands Under-21 international, also linked with Celtic; Slade attributed the fervent speculation to sources within the Netherlands.

Beyond individual sagas, Slade articulated a broader ambition: to secure up to three new signings, critically a striker, to ignite the Bluebirds' faltering push for a Championship play-off berth, with the club currently four points adrift of the top six. This pursuit was intensified by the recent departure of last season's top scorer, Kenwyne Jones, to Al Jazira. While the Trinidad and Tobago international publicly claimed on social media that the club had offered him no fresh deal, Slade robustly countered, asserting that "a dialogue was going on between Kenwyne's people, Kenwyne himself and [chief executive] Ken Choo and the board of directors."

Slade further quashed reports from Rotherham manager Neil Redfearn concerning a potential transfer for 32-year-old Alex Revell, who joined Cardiff from Rotherham in January 2015 and has since netted twice in 15 league games. Emphasising the precarious balance of his squad, Slade cautioned: "We've already lost a target type centre forward. We need to be mindful that we're not shooting ourselves in the foot and that we have enough players in every position and every area of the pitch." As these transfer narratives unfolded, Cardiff City prepared to host League One Shrewsbury Town on Sunday in the FA Cup third round, with defender Lee Peltier a significant doubt due to illness.

NHS England has announced a new walk-in "Sore Throat Test and Treat" service, trialled in 35 Boots pharmacies, aimed at reducing both doctor appointments and the overuse of antibiotics. The scheme is expected to significantly cut GP visits, potentially saving the NHS millions annually. This service utilizes a five-minute throat swab test to determine if an illness is viral, meaning drugs will not help, or a bacterial infection. Patients diagnosed with a bacterial infection will be prescribed antibiotics directly by the pharmacist, eliminating the need for a GP appointment.

NHS chief executive Simon Stevens confirmed the national rollout of the scheme over the coming year. Dr. Adam Roberts, a microbiologist at University College London specializing in antibiotic resistance, praised it as "quite an innovative step." He stated, "Anything that reduces our reliance and our inappropriate use of antibiotics is a good thing," highlighting initial data showing prescriptions were issued to only 36 out of around 360 participants, which he called "a massive reduction."

Claire Ward, chairwoman of Pharmacy Voice, welcomed the initiative as fitting for community pharmacies but warned that funding cuts could jeopardize its effectiveness. This concern stems from reports in October by the Pharmaceutical Services Negotiating Committee about proposed government funding reductions of 12% from December, though the Department of Health stated no final decision had been made.

The throat test is one of eight medical innovations being introduced to modernize the NHS in response to increasing demand. Sir Bruce Keogh, NHS England's national medical director, emphasized that "innovation is not an option but a necessity if we are to build a sustainable NHS," adding that these innovations "have the potential to deliver better value for the taxpayer whilst making patient interactions with the NHS safer and more personal."

Sakurajima, the formidable volcano on Japan's Kyushu island, presents a "growing threat," according to researchers at the University of Bristol. This colossal peak, rising just 49 km (30 miles) from the Sendai nuclear plant and overlooking the bustling city of Kagoshima, home to 600,000 residents, has a history marked by devastation, including a deadly 1914 eruption that claimed 58 lives.

As part of the volatile Pacific "Ring of Fire" that scars the Japanese archipelago with over 100 active volcanoes, Sakurajima is a constant source of activity. It regularly belches ash and experiences numerous minor explosions annually, with its most recent outburst recorded in February. Japanese authorities maintain close surveillance, placing Sakurajima at Level 3 on the nation's five-tiered volcanic warning system, a designation that strictly prohibits approach to its hazardous slopes.

Dr. James Hickey, lead author of the recent study and now with the University of Exeter's Camborne School of Mines, revealed the ominous timeline. He noted that the 1914 eruption unleashed approximately 1.5 cubic kilometers of material, and their data suggests it takes about 130 years for the volcano to accumulate a similar volume of magma—meaning we are now just 25 years from that critical threshold.

A collaborative report published Tuesday by Bristol University and the Sakurajima Volcano Research Centre unveiled startling findings: 14 million cubic meters of magma are accumulating beneath the volcano each year, a volume equivalent to filling London's Wembley Stadium 3.5 times over. Crucially, this accumulation rate far exceeds the magma expelled during its routine, smaller eruptions, leading researchers to a stark conclusion: a major eruption is highly probable within the next three decades. These assessments were made possible by innovative new methods for studying and modeling the volcano's subterranean magma reservoir.

Scientists hope these vital insights will empower local authorities to strategize for future cataclysms. Dr. Hickey emphasized the urgency: "We know that being forewarned means we are forearmed and providing essential information for local authorities can potentially help save lives if an eruption was imminent."

In response to the escalating threat, Kagoshima city has already prepared comprehensive new evacuation plans. Dr. Haruhisa Nakamichi, an Associate Professor at Kyoto University’s Disaster Prevention Research Institute, underscored the gravity of the situation: "It has been over 100 years since the 1914 eruption, leaving less than 30 years until the next expected big eruption," he stated, highlighting the city's proactive measures.
